title: Russia withdraws from Chernobyl in Ukraine
content:
On Thursday, Ukraine announced that Russian forces had withdrawn from the abandoned site of the 1986 Chernobyl disaster, a move later confirmed by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). 

Energoatom, the state-owned enterprise responsible for operating Ukraine's nuclear facilities, reported that Russian soldiers had been exposed to radiation while digging trenches in the vicinity of the Chernobyl area. The IAEA indicated that the retreating Russian forces were moving towards Belarus, but did not verify reports of radiation exposure.

Russian troops initially occupied Chernobyl during the early stages of their invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24. The last of the Russian soldiers were reported to have left the site early Friday morning.

title: Fallen power cable kills 26 in Congo-Kinshasa
content:
At least 26 people were killed on Wednesday in the outskirts of Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo, when a lightning strike caused a high-tension power cable to fall near a marketplace.

The country's energy provider reported that the incident occurred during a severe storm and expressed condolences to the victims' families. According to local media and police, the tragedy took place in the Matadi-Kibala district, and the majority of those electrocuted were women working at the market.

Prime Minister [Name] released a statement saying, "I share in the immense pain of the families. My thoughts also go out to all those injured." A government spokesperson mentioned that officials were convening for a crisis meeting to discuss the potential relocation of the market.

The BBC quoted one merchant highlighting that seasonal rains frequently forced buyers and sellers at the market to navigate through flooded areas.

title: Northern Ireland First Minister Paul Givan resigns over Brexit border checks
content:
**DUP First Minister Resigns in Protest Against Goods Checks from the EU**

The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) First Minister of Northern Ireland, Paul Givan, has resigned effective midnight Friday as part of his party's protests against checks on goods arriving from the European Union. 

These checks were introduced under the Northern Ireland Protocol, a key agreement made during Brexit negotiations which facilitated the UK's departure from the EU. However, many prominent figures in Northern Ireland have vehemently opposed the terms of this arrangement.

Givan's resignation will also necessitate the resignation of Sinn Féin's Deputy First Minister, Michelle O’Neill, effectively paralyzing the legislative functions of the devolved government at Stormont. This disruption means that the Executive cannot convene to address critical policies, including a three-year budget, an energy bills grant, and potential easing of COVID-19 restrictions. However, other ministers at Stormont will retain their portfolios until elections scheduled for May.

In an emotional press statement, Givan remarked that Northern Ireland's institutions are "being tested once again" and that the delicate balance established by the Good Friday and St. Andrews agreements has been undermined by the recent UK-EU arrangement. He specifically highlighted the "cornerstone" power-sharing principles introduced by the Belfast Good Friday Agreement.

Givan expressed his sincere hope that all community factions would soon be able to consent to the restoration of a fully functioning executive in order to resolve these pressing issues. Reflecting on his nearly eight-month tenure as First Minister, he described it as "the privilege of my lifetime," having succeeded Arlene Foster after her resignation in June 2021.

The resignation has drawn criticism from opposition parties, with Sinn Féin finance minister Conor Murphy describing it as "reckless and self-serving." Leaders from both the British and Irish governments have also expressed disapproval. Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald called for an early election in light of the absence of a functional Executive, asserting that "the DUP's actions have real consequences for people who are struggling." The leader of the Alliance Party, Naomi Long, framed the situation as destabilizing, warning it could result in "more hardship for the people of Northern Ireland," while ultimately proving futile as the Protocol will remain in place.

McDonald also condemned the DUP for inaction regarding the budget and healthcare investments, saying their focus is on "self-serving political interests." Other officials voiced alarm about the impact on government services, with UK officials calling the move "extremely disappointing" and urging reinstatement to ensure public services are delivered for Northern Ireland residents. Prime Minister Boris Johnson reiterated the UK government’s commitment to a stable Northern Ireland Executive.

Irish Taoiseach Micheál Martin characterized Givan's decision as "highly damaging." Through a spokesperson, he emphasized the importance of the Executive delivering for the people of Northern Ireland, particularly in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. Martin called on the DUP to engage fully with all aspects of the Good Friday Agreement, which the Protocol aims to protect.

Martin also noted that ongoing negotiations between the UK and EU—of which Ireland is a member—need to be given the opportunity to succeed. He pointed out that the European Commission has proposed serious measures to address concerns regarding the Protocol's implementation.

In the wake of Givan's resignation, British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss and European Commission Vice President Maroš Šefčovič held discussions regarding the Protocol. Šefčovič criticized a directive from Stormont's Agriculture Minister and former DUP leader Edwin Poots to suspend certain checks as "very unhelpful." Truss and Šefčovič are scheduled to meet again on February 11.

Unionist politicians have clearly articulated their stance on the Protocol. Following Givan's resignation, DUP leader Jeffrey Donaldson insisted that the Protocol poses an "existential threat" to Northern Ireland's status within the United Kingdom. He accused the UK government of failing to uphold the agreements that led to the DUP’s return to the Executive in January 2020, thus ending a three-year power-sharing impasse with Sinn Féin.

Sources indicate that Givan's resignation and its timing were confirmed during a high-level meeting among DUP leaders earlier Thursday.

Poots’s decision to suspend certain sanitary and phytosanitary checks, which had not been imposed by the December 31, 2020 deadline, was reportedly based on legal advice suggesting he had the authority to do so without Executive approval. Although the UK government has stated it will not intervene since this is a matter for the Northern Ireland Executive, it has faced criticism from Irish Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney, who labeled it a "breach of international law." Šefčovič reaffirmed the necessity of continuing these checks, while a spokesperson for Johnson emphasized the importance of reaching a swift resolution.

title: Washington D.C. football team replaces controversial name with "Commanders"
content:
The American football team based in Washington, D.C., announced on Wednesday that it will adopt a new name, the **Washington Commanders**. 

Previously known as the Washington Redskins, the team competes in the National Football League (NFL). Over the years, various organizations have criticized the use of Native American names and imagery by sports teams. The Washington team faced heightened scrutiny, as the term "Redskins" has been described as "a dictionary-defined slur," which sets it apart from more general terms like “Indians” or “Braves.”

During the announcement, team president **Jason Wright** stated that the new name "embodies the values of service and leadership that characterize the [D.C., Maryland, Virginia region]." Current and former players expressed enthusiasm for the new uniforms, which prominently feature a letter "W." Wright noted that while the name might lack historical significance, the excitement of the players in their new gear would soon engage fans.

Team owner **Daniel Snyder** had long resisted changing the name, even threatening to emphasize it by capitalizing all letters. However, faced with mounting pressure, including a letter from 87 sponsors—covering major companies like **Nike** and **Pepsi**—requesting a change, the team began to reconsider its branding. Complaints about the outdated name's impact on Native American communities also surged. To aid in the renaming process, the team enlisted consultant **John Wright**, who sought input from fans, former players, and Native Americans. While some fans favored "Red Wolves," many variations of that name had already been trademarked.

Reactions from Native American advocates were mixed. Crystal Echo Hawk of ***IllumiNative*** emphasized that while the change is a step forward, there is still significant healing to be done. She remarked, "There's still a lot of healing that needs to happen, so I don't think the team's work in regards to reconciliation and healing is over."

In contrast, **Fawn Sharp**, president of the ***National Congress of American Indians (NCAI)***, criticized the team's management for failing to adequately address the harm caused by its former name: "Without an apology, without any measure of accountability, and without fulfilling the honored commitments they made to tribal nations in 2020 to right this wrong, the NFL and Snyder are simply 'Commanding' a continued course of open, intentional and profit-driven racism and erasure."

Currently, around one thousand sports teams across the United States still use Native American names, a decrease from approximately three thousand in the 1990s. Advocacy groups like the ***NCAI*** and others continue to push for teams to adopt names and mascots that do not draw from Native American culture.

title: Fire destroys central market in Somaliland's capital
content:
On Friday, a significant fire erupted in the Waheen Market in Hargeisa, the capital of Somaliland. The incident resulted in 28 injuries, but thankfully, no fatalities have been reported.

The fire started around 8:00 PM local time (5:00 PM UTC), and firefighters faced challenges accessing the site. They managed to bring the flames under control by early Saturday morning. The cause of the fire has yet to be determined. In response to the disaster, Somaliland's president visited the market and pledged $1 million in aid, indicating that damages could total in the millions of dollars.

The Waheen Market, which houses over 2,000 shops, accounts for 40-50% of Hargeisa's economy, according to Jamal Aideed, chairman of the Hargeisa Chamber of Commerce. The city, with a population of 1.2 million, was gearing up for increased activity as it marked the first day of Ramadan.

The President of Somalia reached out to express condolences, while the Prime Ministers of Ethiopia and the United Kingdom, including Boris Johnson, also extended their support.

Since declaring independence from Somalia in 1991, Somaliland has operated as an autonomous region, although it remains unrecognized as an independent state by the international community.

title: Ballarat residents protest for climate action
content: Australia — Residents of Ballarat, a rural city in Australia, took to the streets on Sunday for a climate action rally. The event began at 1 PM outside the Ballarat Civic Hall and proceeded down Mair, Lydiard, and Sturt Streets, passing the office of a local MP before arriving at the Ballarat Town Hall. At the Town Hall, representatives from several organizations, including Ballarat Renewable Energy and Zero Emissions (BREAZE), Extinction Rebellion’s Ballarat branch, Environment Victoria, the Public Transport Users Association, and the Ballarat Trades Hall, delivered speeches. Although no political candidates addressed the crowd, independent candidate Alex Graham and member John Barnes, both of whom are running for election, were in attendance.

title: Australian Open: Nadal wins 21st Grand Slam
content:
On Sunday, Spanish tennis star Rafael Nadal clinched his 21st Grand Slam title at the Australian Open, defeating Russian player Daniil Medvedev.

There were concerns about Nadal's participation in the tournament due to a foot injury, but he proved his doubters wrong. The match began with Medvedev taking the first set 6-2 in just 42 minutes. However, Nadal fought back, securing the fourth set with a score of 6-4. In a thrilling final set, Nadal sealed the victory 7-5 after a grueling 5 hours and 24 minutes.

With his victory, Nadal surpassed his greatest rivals, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer, to win the most men's singles titles in Grand Slam history. In a heartfelt court interview, Nadal expressed, "It has been one of the most emotional matches in my tennis career, and to share the court with you [Medvedev] was an honor."

Medvedev acknowledged his defeat with grace, thanking his team and humorously adding, "I'm sure my wife is watching back home, but I think the TV will be broken now." He praised Nadal's performance, stating, "He [Nadal] was really strong; the way he played for four hours surprised me."

Earlier in the tournament, Nadal had reached the finals by defeating Italian player Matteo Berrettini in the semi-finals.

Last year was a challenging one for Nadal, as he missed both Wimbledon due to fatigue and the US Open due to the same foot injury that threatened his Australian Open participation. Reflecting on his comeback, Nadal admitted, "One month and a half ago, I would have said it would be my last Australian Open, but now I have a lot of energy to carry on." He concluded his post-match remarks by stating he was "physically destroyed," but filled with triumph.

title: Deadly floods in Brazil after heavy rainfall
content:
Brazil has been grappling with severe rainfall since Friday, leading to at least 24 fatalities and displacing thousands of residents. 

The state's governor announced on Sunday that emergency services are being mobilized to assist the 27 affected cities. According to government reports, approximately half a million families have been forced to leave their homes due to the extreme weather conditions, and many highways and roads remain impassable. 

São Paulo, the most populous state in Brazil, also includes the nation’s largest city, São Paulo.

title: UAE to impose corporate tax on business profits
content:
On Monday, the United Arab Emirates announced the introduction of a federal corporate tax set at 9% on business profits, effective June 1, 2023.

This tax will apply to all corporations, with the exception of those engaged in the extraction of natural resources. Businesses generating profits up to 375,000 AED will be classified as small businesses and will be exempt from the tax.

Historically, the UAE has been known for its low tax environment, with no personal income tax. The government stated that this new tax measure aims to address economic challenges and align the country with significant global trends, including the digitalization of the economy. While the announcement may be associated with a recent international agreement on establishing a minimum global corporate tax rate, the Ministry did not provide further details.

title: Brothers Sunshine Coast pick up first win in senior rugby at Australia's University of the Sunshine Coast
content:
Brothers Sunshine Coast celebrated their first victory in senior rugby union on Friday night, securing a 10-5 win over University in Round 4 of the Sunshine Coast Cup in Australia.

“It was a great effort,” said Brothers second-rower Kalani O'Neill in an interview with Wikinews. “The conditions weren't ideal as it was quite wet out there, but we played as a cohesive unit and managed to clinch the victory. In the end, it turned into a solid performance.”

The heavy rain throughout the day significantly affected the gameplay for both teams, leading to a waterlogged pitch. Consequently, both sides opted to keep their play close to the breakdown.

O'Neill also praised his teammate Jacko Jackson, highlighting the forward's relentless intensity during the match. “Jacko was exceptional; he consistently targeted his opponents and made crucial tackles. He helped create space for us by working the corners,” O'Neill noted.

Despite the encouraging win, O'Neill emphasized that the team will not allow it to define their season. “We’ve got 12 more rounds ahead of us,” he stated. “Our goal is to stay focused and continue pushing forward.”

title: Indian Prime Minister Modi attends 5th BIMSTEC summit virtually
content:
On Wednesday, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi participated in the fifth BIMSTEC summit, which was held virtually under the chairmanship of Sri Lanka. 

The summit's theme, "Towards a Resilient Region, Prosperous Economies, Healthy People," set the stage for Modi's remarks, in which he suggested that this summit could mark an important milestone in the region's history. He announced India’s commitment of $1 million to the BIMSTEC secretariat to improve its operational budget and an additional $3 million for the development of the BIMSTEC Centre for Weather and Climate, which will play a crucial role in regional disaster management.

During the summit, all seven member states signed an official BIMSTEC charter, formalizing the grouping as a cohesive regional organization. Additionally, three significant memorandums were endorsed, focusing on security, technology, and diplomacy. A "Master Plan for Transport Connectivity" was also a key point of discussion among the leaders, aimed at enhancing regional transportation and movement.

In his address, Modi emphasized the need for further development within BIMSTEC, highlighting the importance of maritime cooperation, disaster management, economic integration, and security. He advocated for mutual free trade among member states and raised concerns about international stability in light of recent turmoil in Europe, calling for increased regional cooperation.

The summit underscored the significance of the Bay of Bengal as a "bridge of connectivity, prosperity, and security." At the conclusion of the event, Sri Lanka transferred the chairmanship to Thailand, setting the stage for the next BIMSTEC summit. The other member states include Bangladesh, Bhutan, Myanmar, and Nepal.

title: Victoria approves Delburn wind power farm in Australia
content:
A proposal for a 33-turbine wind farm in a pine tree plantation near Delburn, a town in Gippsland, Australia, received approval from the Victorian Planning Minister on March 27, though the news was first reported late Tuesday. Plans for a battery energy storage system are currently on hold due to fire safety concerns. Set to be constructed by OSMI Australia Pty in 2023, this wind farm will be the first of its kind in a plantation in Victoria.

In late 2021, a planning panel reviewed input from local residents, community groups, and representatives from OSMI. Their subsequent 224-page report recommended approval for the wind farm but noted that the information regarding the siting and fire safety measures for the battery energy storage system was insufficient to endorse it at this time.

OSMI's Executive Director, Peter Marriott, emphasized that the battery energy storage system is "certainly not a key part of the project," but expressed openness to the idea, stating, "We're keen to consider the findings of the recommendations from the investigation into the battery fire."

Member for Gippsland South, Danny O'Brien, highlighted a recent court ruling that required another wind farm to cease nighttime noise emissions, questioning how the Minister could approve the Delburn project despite significant local opposition. He added, "Given Gippsland's relatively densely populated landscape, the appropriate location for wind farms is offshore, and I strongly support proposed developments like the Star of the South."

Meanwhile, Voices of the Valley, a local community group formed after the Hazelwood power station closure, welcomed the wind farm's approval. Group President Wendy Farmer remarked, "Power stations have dominated the landscape over the past century in the valley, but now we are witnessing a transformation in energy across the region." She also highlighted that this approval coincides with the fifth anniversary of the Hazelwood power station's shutdown.

title: Federal judge rejects hate crime plea in Arbery killing
content:
On Monday, a judge in Georgia rejected a guilty plea from Travis McMichael, who had offered to plead guilty to federal hate crimes related to the murder of Ahmaud Arbery.

It is uncommon for a U.S. judge to turn down a plea agreement, especially one that would have waived McMichael's right to appeal.

McMichael expressed his willingness to admit to attacking Arbery out of racial animosity, thus classifying Arbery's murder as a hate crime. Under the proposed plea deal, he would have served the first 30 years of his sentence in federal prison before transferring to a Georgia state prison for the remainder of his life. Even if his state charges were overturned, he would still face a lengthy prison term.

In court, federal prosecutors urged Judge Wood to accept the plea deal, while members of Arbery's family opposed it. Wanda Cooper-Jones, Arbery's mother, stated that allowing the defendants to choose their prison conditions would feel like a betrayal: "Granting these men their preferred choice of confinement would defeat me. It gives them one last chance to spit in my face."

Prosecutors indicated they had previously consulted with Arbery's family about the plea deal, but Cooper-Jones' legal team contradicted that assertion.

title: Russia and China sign major gas pipeline deal for 30 years
content:
On Friday, Russia finalized a significant 30-year agreement to supply natural gas to China, further solidifying the energy partnership between the two nations. During a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Russian President Vladimir Putin pledged to enhance trade exports from Russia to China. This meeting occurred while Putin was visiting China.

Under the terms of the new deal, Russia intends to boost its gas exports to China by 10 billion cubic meters annually, contributing to a total supply of 48 billion cubic meters per year. The project is estimated to be valued at approximately $117.5 billion. Russian energy giant Gazprom has committed to participating in the deal by providing the gas. According to a statement from Gazprom, the project is expected to commence within two to three years.

Putin highlighted the significance of the agreement, stating, "A step forward has been made in the gas industry." Russia currently supplies gas to China through the Power of Siberia pipeline. Furthermore, this deal will be denominated in local currencies as part of ongoing efforts by both countries to reduce their reliance on the US dollar in foreign trade.

title: US attorney Michael Avenatti found guilty of stealing from client
content:
Yesterday, former attorney Michael Avenatti was convicted of fraud and aggravated identity theft, having defrauded adult film actress Stormy Daniels out of hundreds of thousands of dollars. Daniels was in the process of publishing a memoir in 2018 that detailed her alleged affair with then-President Donald Trump.

Testimony revealed that Avenatti persuaded Daniels' agent to redirect payments from her book publisher to an account that he controlled, all without her knowledge.

Avenatti was found guilty by a jury in federal court in Manhattan, New York, where he represented himself during the trial. Sentencing is set for May 24. Avenatti had previously been convicted in 2020 for attempting to extort millions from the sports brand Nike.

title: Russia threatens Wikipedia with 4 million ruble fine for coverage of war in Ukraine
content:
On Thursday, Russia's communications agency, Roskomnadzor, threatened to impose a fine of 4 million rubles (approximately $47,000) on Wikipedia if it fails to remove certain information regarding the war in Ukraine from its articles.

Roskomnadzor described the disputed content as "unreliable socially significant materials" and other prohibited information, accusing Wikipedia of intentionally misleading the Russian public. However, the agency did not specify which details it wanted to be removed.

New guidelines issued by Roskomnadzor last month prohibit language that identifies the conflict as a war. This has led many independent Russian news outlets and journalists to either shut down or leave the country.

In a previous warning, Roskomnadzor stated that Wikipedia included "inaccurate information" about the "special military operation" aimed at protecting the Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics and the de-militarization and de-Nazification of Ukraine.

The Wikipedia article counters these claims, stating they are unsupported by evidence and includes information about the casualties among both Ukrainian civilians and Russian soldiers.

A spokesperson for the Wikimedia Foundation confirmed that the Russian government had requested changes on two occasions, March 1 and March 29. The spokesperson emphasized, "The Wikimedia Foundation supports everyone's fundamental right to access free, open, and verifiable information; this escalation does not change our commitment."

In response to the earlier requests, the Foundation expressed concern that such demands amounted to "censorship," noting that removing the content could have severe consequences for those deprived of access to it.

According to the Wikimedia Foundation, the English Wikipedia page on the war had garnered 11 million views as of March 8 and has been translated into 99 other languages.

title: 30,000-year-old Austrian statue traced to stone from Italy
content:
In a study published on Monday, scientists from Vienna, Austria, revealed that the stone used to create the 30,000-year-old Venus of Willendorf sculpture originated from northern Italy, hundreds of miles away across the Alps.

The Venus of Willendorf, one of the earliest examples of human art, stands about 4.4 inches tall and depicts a female figure characterized by an exaggerated stomach and breasts. Unlike many other prehistoric statuettes carved from ivory or bone, this iconic piece is made from oolite, a sedimentary rock. Researchers believe it was crafted by members of the Gravettian culture, likely using rudimentary tools. The sculpture is named after Venus, the Roman goddess of love.

To determine the stone's origins, scientists compared rock samples from as far west as France to as far east as Ukraine with microscopic images of the Venus. Oolite is formed through the gradual accumulation of silt and other materials, allowing researchers to identify individual grains and shell fragments. One fragment embedded in the statue originated from a creature that existed during the late Pleistocene epoch, although the stone itself would have been extracted and sculpted much later.

In contrast to previous analyses that focused solely on the exterior of the Venus, scientists employed advanced imaging techniques to examine the interior of the statue without causing damage. Their scans indicated that the Venus bears little resemblance to local oolites near Willendorf but closely matches those found in Italy, just across the Danube and Inn rivers, more than 300 miles away. A less likely candidate for the stone's origin is a site in Ukraine, located approximately 600 miles east of where the statue was discovered in 1908.

Lead author Gerhard Weber suggested that the movement of the stone might have coincided with prehistoric migrations: "When the climate or the prey situation changed, [people] moved on, preferably along rivers," he explained.

These findings shed new light on how prehistoric humans navigated and traveled in and around the Alpine region.

The study was supported by funding from the state of Austria.

title: Tonga enters lockdown after detecting new COVID-19 cases
content:
Tongan Prime Minister Sovaleni announced yesterday that the country will enter a lockdown starting today, following the detection of two COVID-19 cases among workers involved in handling foreign aid in the capital.

Officials reported an additional three coronavirus cases among the family members of the port workers. Tonga had previously remained largely unscathed by the virus, with only one reported case prior to this outbreak.

In his address, Sovaleni emphasized the lockdown was essential to "slow down and stop those who have been affected." He also announced the suspension of all boat and aircraft services between islands to curb the virus's spread.

The island nation has been receiving foreign aid from various countries after facing significant challenges from recent disasters. Tongan authorities have implemented a strict "no-contact" policy regarding the handling of foreign aid to ensure safety.

title: Mass protests prompt Sri Lankan cabinet to resign
content:
On Monday, all but President and Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa resigned from the Sri Lankan cabinet, amidst growing public discontent over the government's handling of the ongoing crisis.

In a bid to address the unrest, the President earlier called for all political parties to unite and form a national unity government. However, this proposal was rejected by two key parties—the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP)—which demanded the President’s resignation instead.

Following the mass resignation of the Cabinet, the Governor of the Central Bank also announced his resignation.

The economic crisis has compelled the government to block imports since March 2020, in an attempt to conserve foreign reserves. As of February, Sri Lanka had only about USD 2 billion in reserves— a staggering 70% drop over the past two years. The country requires USD 7 billion to manage its USD 51 billion debt due this year.

In recent weeks, an acute shortage of fuel, particularly diesel, has triggered widespread protests and resulted in empty fuel stations across the nation.

Inflation rates in Sri Lanka surged to 18.7% in March, with food prices increasing by 30.1%. Additionally, the Sri Lankan rupee has fallen by 30% against the US dollar since its recent devaluation, which was implemented in preparation for negotiations with the International Monetary Fund for a potential bailout.

title: Proud Boys chapter leader pleads guilty in US Capitol attack
content:
On Friday, Charles Donohoe, leader of the North Carolina chapter of the Proud Boys, pleaded guilty to felony charges of conspiracy to obstruct the United States Congress and assaulting a law enforcement officer during the events of January 6, 2021.

Donohoe's plea agreement includes his cooperation with federal prosecutors in their investigations into the Proud Boys and its leadership. Several other alleged leaders, including national chairman Enrique Tarrio, have pleaded not guilty to charges of seditious conspiracy. Prosecutors claim they were part of an elite group known as the "Ministry of Self Defense," selected by Tarrio.

Court filings revealed that Donohoe provided the Proud Boys with radio transmitters for communication before and during the Capitol attack. Tarrio had been arrested two days prior to the riot. Following his arrest, Donohoe deleted the group's messages on a communication platform and expressed concern that their plans might be compromised, stating, "Well at least they won't get our boots on the ground plan because we are one step ahead of them," in a subsequent message.

Although Donohoe was among the first wave of individuals approaching the Capitol, he did not enter the building as he was affected by pepper spray. His assault charges are related to his actions of throwing two water bottles at Capitol Police officers. He also reportedly sent messages indicating, "We stormed the Capitol unarmed… we took it over."

The assault on the Capitol occurred while Congress was in the process of certifying the results of the 2020 presidential election, which was won by Joe Biden. The Proud Boys supported a second term for former President Donald Trump.

title: Lost Antarctic shipwreck from 1915 Shackleton expedition, Endurance, rediscovered
content:
The shipwreck of the **Endurance**, the vessel that carried Sir Ernest Shackleton's British expedition to Antarctica in 1915, was rediscovered beneath Antarctic waters on March 7, as announced yesterday.

This significant find by the **Endurance22 expedition** comes more than a century after the ship was trapped off the Antarctic coast, ultimately succumbing to the pressures of shifting sea ice.

Remarkably, the vessel was found to be in excellent condition, preserved by the icy depths. The ship's timbers appear intact, and the name **Endurance** is clearly visible beneath the stern, alongside the five-pointed star **Polaris**—both undeterred by the passage of time.

Submersibles launched by the Endurance22 expedition, formed and funded by the **Falklands Maritime Heritage Trust**, deployed cameras at a depth of approximately **3,008 meters**. These remote vehicles were launched from the expedition’s main hub, the South African icebreaker **Agulhas II**.

The Endurance was the flagship of Shackleton’s ambitious expedition aimed at completing the first land crossing of Antarctica. When the vessel was trapped in sea ice and gradually crushed, Shackleton and his crew camped on the ice until they could launch lifeboats for their eventual escape. Remarkably, all crew members survived, although the Endurance was lost to the depths.

For many years, locating the wreck was a formidable challenge due to the thick year-round sea ice covering the **Weddell Sea**. However, recent months have seen the lowest levels of Antarctic sea ice recorded since the advent of satellite monitoring, enabling the multinational team assembled by the Falklands Maritime Heritage Trust to uncover the ship.

Expedition leader **Dr. John Shears** expressed the significance of the find, stating, "We have made polar history... and successfully completed the world’s most challenging shipwreck search." He highlighted the achievement of humanity's collaborative efforts in overcoming obstacles.

**Menson Bound**, director of exploration, added, "This endeavor isn't solely about the past; we aim to share Shackleton's story and the legacy of Endurance with new audiences and future generations. We hope our discovery will inspire young people with the pioneering spirit, courage, and resilience of those who sailed Endurance to Antarctica, as they will play a crucial role in safeguarding our polar regions and the planet."

title: Ballarat candidates debate climate at election forum
content:
**Candidates Discuss Climate Policy at Ballarat Forum**

Australia — As the upcoming election approaches, four candidates for the local seat met last Sunday at the Ballarat Tech School to discuss climate issues in a forum organized by the local group, Ballarat Renewable Energy and Zero Emissions (BREAZE).

The candidates in attendance were incumbent MP Catherine King, Greens candidate and former mayor John Barnes, Australian Federation Party candidate Kerryn Sedgman, and independent candidate Alex Graham. Representatives from the local Liberal and National parties sent their apologies for not being able to attend.

The forum kicked off following a climate action rally held outside the Ballarat Civics Hall and Town Hall. The rally featured speeches from BREAZE members, representatives from the Ballarat branch of various environmental organizations, and the Ballarat Trades Hall.

Each candidate began with a three-minute summary of their climate policies before fielding questions from the audience. John Barnes opened for the Greens, stating, "The Greens have the most ambitious program of any party addressing climate change." He emphasized the party's commitment to achieving a 75% reduction in emissions by 2030 and ending coal mining, burning, and export.

Independent candidate Alex Graham expressed his passion for environmental issues and touted the superiority of his policy, which focuses on introducing a referendum allowing the government to create its own money supply. He argued that this funding could rejuvenate the environment.

Catherine King reflected on her two decades in Parliament, acknowledging previous attempts by the last Labor government to enact climate policies, including the Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme, which were later dismantled. She highlighted the Labor Party's Powering Australia policy, promising a 43% reduction in emissions by 2030 and net zero by 2050.

Kerryn Sedgman of the Australian Federation Party positioned community perspectives at the forefront of her climate approach. She emphasized that "carbon is not the enemy; toxic pesticides are the true enemy," attributing major nitrous oxide emissions to pesticide use.

Following their opening remarks, candidates responded to questions from the public about their top priorities for climate action. Barnes indicated that immediate action and economic transformation were crucial, while Graham suggested that limitless money would solve climate issues. King focused on increasing renewable energy sources, and Sedgman stressed the importance of soil regeneration.

The discussion briefly veered off topic as a disruptive attendee raised questions about an unrelated conspiracy theory, but organizers swiftly managed the situation.

The forum then examined the proposed Western Victorian Transmission Network. Graham proposed that his referendum could enable the federal government to subsidize underground transmission lines rather than overhead, stressing the need to prioritize ecological preservation over financial considerations. King acknowledged concerns about a proposed transfer station's location while advocating for regulatory reform.

Candidates addressed questions regarding carbon capture technology and commitment to halting new coal and gas infrastructure. King clarified that while Labor does not support a moratorium on new projects, it does not seek to invest taxpayer funds in them. In contrast, Graham affirmed his commitment to closing existing coal-fired power stations and prohibiting new constructions.

During a discussion on job transitions for coal communities, candidates shared their visions for supporting affected workers as Australia shifts towards renewable energy. Graham advocated for a universal basic wage, while King emphasized the importance of retraining and creating renewable energy jobs. Barnes highlighted the Greens' $19 billion plan to assist communities transitioning away from fossil fuels, ensuring the maintenance of existing incomes for displaced workers.

The forum concluded with a presentation from Environment Victoria, which introduced an open letter signed by 125 community members. The letter called for accelerated climate action plans that include a transition away from fossil fuels and a coordinated national effort to reduce climate pollution.

title: Indian singer Lata Mangeshkar dies at age 92
content:
On Sunday, Indian singer Lata Mangeshkar passed away at the age of 92. She succumbed to complications at a hospital in Mumbai, where she had been admitted after testing positive for COVID-19 on January 11.

Widely regarded as the 'Nightingale of India,' Mangeshkar was an iconic figure in the Indian film industry. In 2001, she received India's highest civilian honor, the Bharat Ratna, followed by France's highest civilian award, the Legion of Honor, in 2007.

The Indian government has declared two days of national mourning in her memory, starting on Sunday. During this time, the national flag will be flown at half-mast across the country to pay tribute to the beloved singer. Mangeshkar was given a state funeral in Mumbai on Sunday.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated that Mangeshkar has left a "void in our nation that cannot be filled." He also expressed that the news of her passing was "heart-breaking for me, as it is for millions around the world," extending his condolences. Players from the Indian cricket team donned black armbands to honor her memory during their match.

Pakistani Minister for Information and Broadcasting Fawad Chaudhry expressed his sorrow over her death. Additionally, Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina wrote a condolence letter to Modi, conveying solidarity and stating that "the people of Bangladesh mourn in solidarity with the people of India in this hour of grief."

title: Gunman kills three, wounds several others in Tel Aviv, Israel
content:
**Gunman Kills Three, Wounds Nine in Tel Aviv Shooting Before Being Neutralized by Security Forces**

On Thursday evening, a gunman opened fire in an entertainment district of Tel Aviv, Israel, resulting in the deaths of three individuals and injuries to at least nine others. The shooter was later located and killed in a confrontation with security forces early Friday morning.

Israel's national emergency medical service reported receiving the first call about the incident at 9:00 PM local time. Victims were transported to three different hospitals, where two men were pronounced dead at the scene, and a third succumbed to his injuries shortly after. Three individuals are currently in serious condition, while four others sustained minor injuries.

The shooting began at a pub, where five victims were reported, before the attacker moved on to J. L. Gordon Street and surrounding areas. Security forces shot and killed the alleged gunman after an exchange of gunfire near a mosque in southern Tel Aviv. Authorities identified the suspect as a 29-year-old Palestinian man from a city in the northern West Bank.

In a statement made on Friday, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett expressed condolences to the families of the victims and extended wishes for a swift recovery to the injured. He noted that the perpetrator was not affiliated with any known organization but had received support and weaponry from others. "Those who assist and support terrorists should be aware that the consequences will be severe," Bennett asserted.

Bennett also claimed that celebrations erupted in Jenin following news of the attack, mentioning having witnessed the father of the shooter encouraging further violence and expressing pride in his son's actions. "As a nation, we must remain patient and vigilant, but above all, we should have unwavering faith in the justice of our cause in this land," he added.

U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken released a statement emphasizing that the U.S. is closely monitoring the situation and maintaining regular communication with Israeli counterparts, reaffirming their solidarity against senseless acts of terrorism and violence.

March has seen several attacks in Israel, including a shooting east of Tel Aviv that claimed five lives.

title: US Senate confirms Ketanji Brown Jackson for Supreme Court
content:
On Thursday, the United States Senate confirmed Ketanji Brown Jackson as an associate justice of the Supreme Court, making history as the first Black woman to serve on the Court. 

The Senate voted 53-47 in favor of Jackson, with the results largely falling along party lines. Notably, Republicans Susan Collins (Maine), Mitt Romney (Utah), and Lisa Murkowski (Alaska) broke with their party to support her nomination. Vice President Kamala Harris presided over the proceedings and was prepared to cast a tiebreaking vote if necessary.

Jackson and President Joe Biden watched the confirmation process unfold from the White House. Biden nominated Jackson on February 25 to succeed retiring Justice Stephen Breyer, fulfilling a promise he made during his presidential campaign to appoint a Black woman to the Supreme Court. All presidential nominations must be confirmed by the Senate.

During her introduction to the Senate on March 21, Jackson was accompanied by former D.C. Circuit Judge Merrick Garland. In her opening remarks, she shared her belief that her journey was made possible by the sacrifices of her parents: "They taught me that, unlike the many barriers that they had to face growing up, my path was clearer... [In the U.S.], I could do anything or be anything I wanted to be."

She concluded her address with a commitment to upholding the Constitution: "If I am confirmed, I commit to you that I will work productively to support and defend the Constitution and this grand experiment of American democracy that has endured through the past 246 years. I hope that you will see how much I love our country and the Constitution and the rights that make us free."

During the second day of confirmation hearings, Senator Josh Hawley (Republican; Missouri) probed Jackson about her sentencing decisions in child pornography cases, specifically questioning a three-month sentence she imposed in United States v. Hawkins, where prosecutors had requested a two-year term. Jackson defended her decision by arguing that the standards for sentencing are flawed and do not consider individual circumstances of defendants.

Jackson stated, "Congress has given judges the discretion to make decisions on an individualized basis, taking into account not only the guidelines but also various factors including the age of the defendant and the context of the case." In Hawkins, the defendant was eighteen years old.

On the third day of the hearings, Jackson addressed how to interpret Constitutional provisions written over two centuries ago. She explained, "It’s a process of understanding what the core foundational principles are in the Constitution and applying those principles to modern-day issues."

Senators Lindsey Graham (Republican; South Carolina) and Ted Cruz (Republican; Texas) continued their inquiries regarding Jackson’s past sentencing decisions, which led to frequent interventions from Judiciary Committee Chair Senator Dick Durbin (Democrat; Illinois) on Jackson's behalf. Despite assertions that Jackson was being interrupted, some accused Durbin of filibustering in support of her nomination.

During the final day of hearings on March 24, Durbin announced that the Judiciary Committee would convene on March 28, setting up a potential vote on Jackson for April 4. On this day, Jackson was absent as the Senate heard testimony from other witnesses, including Wade Henderson, president of the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, who praised Jackson's qualifications, stating, "Her background is absolutely extraordinary and her mastery of the law is second to none."

Senator Marsha Blackburn (Republican; Tennessee) requested access to confidential pre-sentencing reports in Jackson's prior child pornography cases, which are typically protected to safeguard victims. Durbin advised against this, saying, "I would not want that on my conscience... I'm going to resist it every step of the way."

On April 4, the Judiciary Committee reached an 11-11 deadlock on Jackson’s nomination. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (New York) called a vote to break the tie, sending her nomination to the Senate floor for final consideration.

Before her nomination, Jackson had an extensive legal background, having served as a law clerk for Justice Breyer, as a federal district court judge, a member of the U.S. Sentencing Commission, and as an attorney in private practice.

The Supreme Court is composed of eight associate justices and one chief justice.

title: United States bans importation of Russian fossil fuels
content:
On Tuesday, President Joe Biden announced a ban on imports of oil, gas, and coal from Russia in response to the invasion of Ukraine that began last month.

Biden stated, "The United States is targeting the main artery of Russia's economy," while acknowledging that many allied nations may not be able to implement similar restrictions. 

"The decision made today comes with consequences for Americans," he added. "Putin's war is already impacting families at the gas pump. Since the start of Putin's military build-up at Ukraine's borders, gas prices in the U.S. have increased by 75 cents, and this action will likely lead to further increases. I will do everything in my power to mitigate Putin's price hike in the U.S."

While the U.S. seeks to cut ties with Russian fuel, European countries are more heavily dependent on Russian energy imports. Throughout the announcement, Biden consistently referred to the invasion as "Vladimir Putin's war."

title: Entomological Society of America renames invasive moth
content:
On Wednesday, America officially renamed the caterpillar previously known as the "gypsy moth" to "spongy moth" as part of its Better Naming Project. The scientific name remains unchanged.

The decision to eliminate the common name was announced last July, but a new name was not selected until last week when the Society voted unanimously to adopt "spongy moth." 

Romani scholar Magda Matache of the Roma Program emphasized the significance of this change, stating, "Gypsy is considered a racial slur by many Romani people. It carries a painful history and is offensive." The Romani, or Roma, have historically faced significant prejudice in both Europe and North America.

The 57 members of the Project assigned to this species gathered input from the public and reviewed over 200 proposed names. "Spongy moth," derived from the French term for "spongy," was first suggested in January. The name reflects the sponge-like appearance of the egg masses that protect the larvae through the winter.

Additionally, the name aligns with those used in other languages, such as "sponge-spinner" in German and "sponge-knitter" in Dutch. According to CNN, the spongy moth is most likely to spread to new areas during its egg stage, as they can easily be transported on firewood or vehicles.

Native to Europe, Asia, and northern Africa, the spongy moth has become a highly destructive pest in North America since its introduction in 1869. The caterpillars are brown, covered in spines, and have distinctive blue and red spots. They can strip trees of their leaves, leading to significant deforestation—approximately 1 million acres of trees have been defoliated annually since 1980.

"They basically chew their way through deciduous forests," noted Jessica Ware from the Entomological Society of America, referencing a children's picture book. "The term 'spongy moth' is already starting to appear in media stories and online resources, which is encouraging. However, we recognize that this name change will take time to fully implement," she added.

"In print media, literature, and regulations concerning L. dispar, integrating the new name may be a gradual process. The Entomological Society of America will continue to provide support for organizations in this transition," Ware stated.

The Entomological Society of America is the largest professional organization for insect scientists worldwide.

title: Financial Action Task Force places United Arab Emirates on money laundering 'grey' list
content:
The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) placed the United Arab Emirates (UAE) on its global grey list on March 4 due to "strategic deficiencies" in combating money laundering, terrorist financing, and proliferation financing, subjecting the country to increased scrutiny.

The UAE joins 23 other countries on the list, which includes regional neighbors like Jordan, Syria, and Yemen, as well as Pakistan and Turkey. While being on the grey list is less severe than a 'black' listing—reserved for countries like Iran and North Korea—it could potentially harm the UAE's reputation as a business-friendly destination.

This status may also lead to less favorable interest rates, increased transaction costs, and heightened competition with neighboring Saudi Arabia. A report from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), published in May 2021, found that grey-listing typically results in an average GDP decline of 7.6%, which would equate to about $27.3 billion based on the UAE's 2020 GDP.

The FATF clarifies that being placed on the grey list implies the country has committed to promptly addressing the identified strategic deficiencies. A follow-up report in November 2021, stemming from a 2020 evaluation, indicated that the UAE made progress in four areas and is considered "compliant" or "highly compliant" with 36 out of 40 FATF recommendations.

Since 2018, the UAE has implemented a federal decree on money laundering to align itself with international standards and has established four specialized courts for prosecution in this arena. In December 2020, the country also set up an Executive Office focused on combating money laundering and terrorist financing. However, the FATF has urged improvements in risk management across specific sectors and called for enhanced capabilities in domestic and international investigations and prosecutions related to money laundering.

The Executive Office affirmed, "The UAE will continue its efforts to identify, disrupt, and penalize criminal and illicit financial networks in accordance with FATF’s recommendations and the UAE’s National Action Plan," and pledged ongoing cooperation with international partners. A former UAE Foreign Affairs Minister expressed on Twitter the country's steadfast commitment to strengthening strategic cooperation with global allies to confront this challenge.

Katherine Bauer, a senior fellow at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, criticized the UAE's "inherent vulnerabilities to illicit finance" due to its role as a regional commercial and financial hub, noting that necessary changes cannot occur overnight.

The UAE was also mentioned in the 2016 Panama Papers leak, which identified it as a hub for financial secrecy. The leak implicated several Emirati officials in suspicious transactions, including the Prime Minister, who has ties to a cybersecurity firm alleged to engage in espionage.

In this context, the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) labeled the UAE as a "center for financial crime," citing that "mass surveillance and the monarchy's tight grip on the courts and media make it difficult to challenge the system or expose dubious business practices." Jodi Vittori, a Fellow at the Center for International Relations, remarked that the U.S. appeared to have overlooked the UAE's role in facilitating illicit finance and organized crime.

The FATF's decision to grey-list the UAE took place during its sixth plenary session held under a German presidency from March 2 to 4. In the same session, Zimbabwe was removed from increased monitoring, and France was acknowledged for having a "robust and sophisticated" regulatory framework, though with areas still in need of improvement.

title: Australian cricketer Shane Warne dies aged 52
content:
Australian cricket legend Shane Warne passed away on Friday at the age of 52, reportedly from a heart attack at a villa on the island of Koh Samui, Thailand. His death occurred just hours after the passing of another fellow Australian cricket player, whom Warne had paid tribute to on Twitter prior to his own demise.

Warne's management released a statement confirming that he was found unresponsive in his villa, and despite the immediate efforts of medical personnel, he could not be revived. 

Tributes have poured in from former and current cricketers across Australia and around the globe, including players from India and Pakistan. Former fiancée Liz Hurley expressed her grief, stating, "I feel like the sun has gone behind a cloud forever. RIP my beloved lionheart."

In Melbourne, fans have adorned Warne's statue with memorabilia such as flowers, beer cans, meat pies, baked beans, and cigarettes. The Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG) announced that its Great Southern Stand will be renamed in honor of Warne as the S.K. Warne Stand.

Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has offered a state funeral for Warne, which has been accepted by the family. Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison expressed his condolences and confirmed that the federal government would support the state funeral.

As of now, the date and location of the funeral have yet to be announced.

title: Grand Finals set in 2021-22 Sunshine Coast, Australia cricket season
content:
Cricket matches on Australia's Sunshine Coast have been scheduled following the cancellation of several semi-finals due to heavy rain.

Three games that were set to be played at various venues were unable to proceed when the local government closed access to all sporting grounds in the area. The affected matches included the Division 3 clash between Burpengary and USC, the Division 1 matchup between Caboolture and another team, and the Division 4 contest between Wamuran-Stanley River and Palmwoods.

No play occurred at two grounds, as the sports club managing those facilities denied access. The matches that could not be played included a Division 4 game between Glasshouse and Maroochydore, and a Division 5 fixture between Glasshouse and USC.

However, one ground in Palmwoods managed to host a game. In the Division 5 encounter at Palmwoods Sports Reserve, the home team batted first and scored 92 runs. Cooroy finished the first day at 52 runs for the loss of 9 wickets, with Palmwoods set to claim the final wicket on Sunday.

The main venue, Read Park, was declared too waterlogged after an inspection by both teams ahead of the Division 1 match between Tewantin Noosa and Glasshouse. On a brighter note, Tewantin's Division 6 side managed to play 61 overs against Yandina on Sunday, but the match concluded in a draw as lightning disrupted play.

USC and Palmwoods achieved a first-innings result in their game, with USC successfully chasing down the required 86 runs about an hour before the scheduled lunch break, leading Palmwoods to concede the match roughly 20 minutes prior to the interval.

George Bagshaw from USC commented, "We bowled well, getting them out for around 86 runs. We then did our job with the bat. Both Travis [Bell] and I put together a good partnership, and it was great for the rest of the boys to finish the game this morning."

title: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un oversees hypersonic missile test
content:
On January 12, North Korea's state-run newspaper reported on a missile launch that took place on Tuesday, which was attended by Kim Jong-un and other high-ranking officials. This launch marked the third missile test conducted by North Korea (DPRK) this year. According to state media, the missile flew for an undisclosed distance before landing in the sea.

State media described the weapon as a demonstration of the DPRK's strength, boasting "superior maneuverability" and asserting that it was test-fired for "final verification of overall technical specifications." However, Leif-Eric Easley, a professor at Ewha University in Seoul, stated in an email to Al Jazeera that the so-called hypersonic weapon was "not technologically ready." Initially, there was some downplaying of the missile's significance, but subsequent reports noted that it displayed "improvement."

Earlier this year, North Korea conducted two missile tests: one on Wednesday and another on Monday, both acknowledged by South Korea and others. The first launch was described by state media as a winter resilience test. North Korea's first hypersonic missile, unveiled on September 28, has drawn attention; defense expert Ankit Panda remarked that last Wednesday's missile was not a Hwasong-8 but a new model showcased at an October weapons exhibition in Pyongyang. After the September test, Panda labeled the Hwasong-8 a "significant milestone" in comments to the BBC.

In response to these missile tests, the UN missions of Albania, France, the Republic of Ireland, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States jointly called for dialogue and condemned the initial test. The U.S. ambassador to the UN described the tests as "a significant threat to regional stability." South Korean President Moon Jae-in expressed concern about the tests as the country's elections approach in March.

Hypersonic missiles are known for their high speed and ability to evade detection longer than conventional missiles, as noted by the BBC.

title: Mass shooting takes place in New York City subway system
content:
On Tuesday at approximately 8:30 a.m. (12:30 GMT), a tragic incident occurred on a train traveling between two stations in Brooklyn, New York, United States.

At least sixteen individuals sustained injuries, including ten who suffered from gunshot wounds. The remaining six were injured in various ways. According to the latest press briefing from the New York Police Department (NYPD) at the scene, there have been no reported fatalities. Additionally, several others received treatment for smoke inhalation and panic attacks.

Officials state that the gunman ignited a device on the northbound train and opened fire on commuters. When the train arrived at 36th Street Station, injured passengers were seen collapsing onto the platform. Preliminary investigations suggest that another smoke device was detonated at the station. The NYPD has confirmed that there are currently no explosive devices present at the scene.

The suspect, described as wearing a reflective vest and gas mask, managed to flee the area. In response, transit authorities have shut down multiple train lines throughout Brooklyn. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has also been called to assist with the investigation.

President Joe Biden has been briefed on the situation. This shooting incident has taken place amidst an increase in gun violence in New York, as reported by NYPD data.

title: Metropolitan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick resigns amid criticism
content:
**Dame Cressida Dick Resigns as Head of Metropolitan Police Following Loss of Support from Mayor Sadiq Khan**

Dame Cressida Dick, the Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police in London, resigned on Thursday after losing the confidence of Mayor Sadiq Khan. Her resignation came just hours after she told the BBC that she had "absolutely no intention" of stepping down. However, in her resignation speech, she acknowledged that Khan "no longer has sufficient confidence in my leadership to continue," adding that the mayor had left her "no choice but to step aside."

Khan had put Dick on notice on February 2, following the release of a report from the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) that detailed "disgraceful" incidents of bullying, discrimination, misogyny, and sexual harassment within the force. Dick had previously weathered several scandals since 2019, including allegations of misleading the public in an inconclusive investigation, but recent criticisms focused on claims of "institutional corruption" in the Metropolitan Police, which Dick has denied.

The February 1 report highlighted troubling behavior among some officers, including racist, sexist, and homophobic remarks made in Facebook and WhatsApp groups from 2016 to 2018. Although nine of the fourteen officers investigated remain on duty, two were promoted from constable to sergeant despite the allegations.

The force faced widespread criticism for its delayed investigation into "Partygate," a series of gatherings at Downing Street that violated Covid-19 restrictions. Sources indicated a feeling of disillusionment within the police and public regarding the Met's ongoing issues, with some attributing the concerns to Dick's perceived defensiveness in addressing the scandals.

In his statement, Khan expressed dissatisfaction with Dick's responses to the urgent demands for reform necessary to rebuild public trust in the Metropolitan Police. He emphasized the need to eradicate the prevalent issues of racism, sexism, homophobia, bullying, and misogyny within the organization, and found an initial meeting with Dick inadequate, prompting her resignation ahead of a follow-up.

The Met's handling of the murder of Sarah Everard by police officer Wayne Couzens also sparked outrage, particularly after four attendees of a vigil for Everard were arrested for breaching Covid-19 restrictions. The force faced further criticism in October when it advised women feeling threatened to shout to passersby or run into nearby homes rather than providing clearer directives.

Both the Metropolitan Police and the government are conducting inquiries into the force's oversight in Everard's case, led by Baroness Casey in the independent government review.

In December, two constables were sentenced to 33 months for sharing inappropriate photos of sisters Bibaa Henry and Nicole Smallman, drawing public outrage. Their mother, Mina Smallman, rejected the force's apology, accusing it of systemic racism and dehumanization.

Earlier during an interview with Radio London, Dick, who had insisted she would not resign, stated that "enough is enough" and expressed her anger over the report's findings. She maintained that the Met is capable in many ways but acknowledged that its reputation has been severely damaged.

Reactions to Dick's resignation have been mixed. Former IOPC superintendent Mehtab reported that her stepping down was a necessary move to address the ongoing "sub-culture" of sexism and racism within the force. Alastair Morgan, whose family has been affected by police failures, noted that while it's unfortunate to see another commissioner resign, it was essential for accountability.

Activist organizations echoed the sentiment, emphasizing the necessity for substantial reforms rather than just a change at the top. Ruth Davidson of the charity stated that one resignation does not resolve the deeper issues within the police, while Mehtab refuted the idea that the problems stem from just a few "bad apples."

However, Dick received support from Ken Marsh, chair of the Metropolitan Police Federation, who stated she should have been given more time to rebuild public trust. Both Khan, Home Secretary Priti Patel, and Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed gratitude for Dick's service, with Johnson acknowledging her dedication.

Khan pledged to collaborate closely with Patel to appoint her successor swiftly, aiming to restore confidence in London's police service. Dick will remain in a caretaker role until a new commissioner is appointed.

Having joined the force as a constable in 1983, Dick led efforts against gang violence before becoming the first female commissioner of the Metropolitan Police in February 2017. Despite her achievements in tackling violent crime, London's teenage homicide rate reached its highest level since 2008 last year.

title: US warns its citizens to leave Ukraine as Russia could invade 'anytime'
content:
Yesterday, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned that Russia's increased troop deployment near its border with Ukraine could signal an imminent invasion. 

During a press conference, Blinken urged all American citizens in Ukraine to evacuate within the next 48 hours to mitigate the risks associated with a potential military incursion. Australia and New Zealand have also issued travel warnings advising their citizens to leave the Eastern European nation. In an NBC News interview on Thursday, President Joe Biden remarked that the situation in Ukraine "could escalate rapidly."

Additionally, Blinken emphasized that American citizens who remain in Ukraine would not receive assistance from the U.S. government if they choose to stay. He reiterated that a Russian invasion could commence without warning.

Russia has denied intentions to invade Ukraine, labeling the Western response as "diplomatically impolite and disrespectful." Recent satellite images released by U.S. intelligence indicate a significant concentration of Russian troops along Ukraine's borders, including areas adjacent to western Russia, the Russian-occupied Crimea, and the Russian ally Belarus.

Furthermore, the U.S. government announced it would suspend all visa and consular services to Ukraine starting tomorrow but will maintain a limited consular presence in the region for emergency situations.

title: Shehbaz Sharif becomes new prime minister of Pakistan
content:
On Monday, Pakistan's National Assembly elected Shehbaz Sharif, the former chief minister of Punjab province, as the country's new prime minister.

This transition follows the ousting of Imran Khan, the previous prime minister since 2018 and leader of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party, who lost a no-confidence vote on Sunday. Before the vote, Khan had dissolved the Assembly in an attempt to call for early elections. However, the Supreme Court of Pakistan ruled the dissolution unconstitutional just a week prior, allowing the Assembly to be reinstated and the vote to proceed.

Sharif secured 174 votes in the 342-seat Assembly, while all 155 PTI members resigned in protest ahead of the vote. Khan has alleged that a conspiracy, supposedly led by the United States, was behind his ousting and has called for nationwide protests. Demonstrations were reported in several cities, including Lahore and Peshawar, where tens of thousands participated.

In his inaugural address to the Assembly, Sharif emphasized the need for hard work and unity, stating, "If we have to save the sinking boat, what we all need is hard work, and unity, unity, and unity. We are beginning a new era of development today." He was subsequently sworn into office at the presidential palace.

Shehbaz Sharif is the younger brother of former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, who was sentenced to ten years in prison for corruption in 2018 but is currently receiving medical treatment abroad. Shehbaz Sharif himself remains under investigation for corruption and could face legal challenges in the future.

title: Teenager fatally stabbed at Sydney Royal Easter Show in Australia
content:
A tragic incident at a Sydney event on Monday evening has left a 17-year-old boy dead and a 16-year-old in serious condition. The fight reportedly broke out around 8 p.m. and resulted in the 17-year-old, who was working at the event, suffering a fatal stab wound to the chest in front of his parents. New South Wales Ambulance Inspector Mark Whittaker confirmed that paramedics attempted resuscitation before transporting him to the hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries. The 16-year-old victim sustained stab wounds to his leg and is currently receiving treatment.

Authorities arrested a 15-year-old boy at the event in connection with the stabbing. He was taken to a police station and has since appeared in juvenile court, where he was granted bail on charges of affray, carrying a knife in public, and being armed with intent.

Detectives are actively searching for additional individuals involved in what is believed to be a premeditated confrontation between two groups, not a random act of violence. The adult section of the carnival was closed to allow for forensic investigation of the scene.

Murray Wilton, the show's manager, defended the event's security measures amid claims of failure, stating that while random bag checks were implemented, it was impractical to check every attendee's belongings. Organizers have also announced that full refunds will be available for anyone who feels uncomfortable attending the show following the incident.

In response to the tragedy, Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison expressed his condolences. "All our kids will be going to the Royal Easter Show. My kids will be going to the Royal Easter Show. We want them to be safe. This is a very distressing event. The violence that is there has no place in this country, nor at an event meant for enjoyment," he stated.

Superintendent Danielle Emerton has reassured the public that safety remains a priority at the event and has called for assistance in identifying other individuals involved in the stabbing. "We know that there were thousands of people at the show last night and that there is a lot of evidence available. We urge anyone with information about the incident to come forward," she said.

title: UK Supreme Court will not hear Julian Assange's appeal against extradition
content:
Yesterday, the United Kingdom announced that it would not decide on Julian Assange's appeal against his extradition to the United States. The court stated that the application "didn’t raise an arguable point of law," upholding a December ruling that deemed Assange eligible for extradition, following assurances from the U.S. regarding humane treatment.

Assange, the Australian founder of WikiLeaks, published classified U.S. military documents obtained from whistleblower Chelsea Manning. He faces criminal charges in the U.S. for allegedly assisting Manning in obtaining these documents. His defense argues that he was acting solely as a journalist.

Since 2019, Assange has been detained in London. Before that, he spent seven years in the Ecuadorian embassy to avoid extradition to Sweden on sexual assault charges, which have since been dropped.

The case now rests with the UK Home Secretary, and Assange's legal team has four weeks to file objections.

title: Court finds UK allowed undervalued Chinese imports into EU
content:
**European Court of Justice Rules UK Neglected Customs Obligations for Chinese Imports**

On Tuesday, the European Court of Justice (ECJ) determined that the United Kingdom failed to uphold its responsibilities as a former European Union member by permitting undervalued imports of textiles and footwear from China to enter EU markets.

The European Commission contended that the UK "failed to fulfill its obligations" under EU law by inadequately collecting customs duties on imports of Chinese clothing and shoes from 2011 to 2017. In 2017, it was reported that over half of these products were imported below the "lowest acceptable prices," a benchmark set by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to identify imports at risk of undervaluation.

OLAF had warned member states—including the UK—about the risks of "extreme undervaluation" during bilateral meetings in 2015 and 2016. However, the ECJ found that British authorities did not apply this metric in their monitoring efforts between 2011 and 2014, which resulted in inadequate customs controls and allowed these products to circulate freely within the EU. For instance, fraud investigators discovered that women’s trousers from China were declared at just €0.91 per kilogram, significantly below the cotton market price of €0.53.

The Commission estimates that this negligence cost the EU budget approximately €2.68 billion (around $2.9 billion) from 2011 to 2017, as approximately 80% of customs duties contribute to the EU budget.

Despite this ruling, the ECJ rejected the Commission's request for the UK to repay the full amount, noting inconsistencies that meant the Commission had not met the required legal standards. The UK remains under ECJ jurisdiction regarding infractions committed during its EU membership, even after leaving the EU in January 2020. Consequently, the UK has been ordered to cover four-fifths of the legal costs incurred by Brussels since OLAF's first allegations of misconduct in 2017.

The UK has the option to challenge the fine but cannot contest the overall judgment. The fine amount of €2.68 billion reflects an increase from the initial estimate of €1.99 billion related to a complex fraud scheme. While today's sum encompasses 2011-2017, the investigation initially concentrated on evidence from 2013-2016 involving ports in England.

At the time, a representative for then-Prime Minister Theresa May stated that the sum was "not a bill, it’s an estimate," emphasizing that the figures were not recognized by the UK government.

The Luxembourg-based court concluded that the British government had failed "to apply effective customs control measures or to record the correct amounts of customs duties." It further indicated that the "inadequate nature of checks carried out by UK customs authorities" allowed fraudulent shell companies to relocate their operations to the UK.

The ECJ also found that the UK had not provided the Commission with all necessary information for accurate calculations.

The UK has expressed opposition to the EU's methods for assessing undervalued goods, a stance supported by countries such as Belgium, Estonia, Greece, Latvia, Portugal, and Slovakia. Among these, Portugal, Slovakia, and the UK—along with Malta and Spain—were identified as having "major undervaluation hubs" during OLAF's 2014 Operation Snake.

British ports, particularly Dover, were highlighted as key entry points for Chinese goods before they cleared European customs and were distributed across the continent. Bruno Collin, head of a French anti-fraud operation in 2016, lamented the lack of cooperation from British authorities, stating that they provided only "extremely vague answers" to French requests, if they responded at all.

In response to OLAF's allegations of the UK's "continuous negligence" in combating fraud, HM Revenue and Customs told Politico Europe that it maintained an "excellent record in tackling fraud and rule-breaking of all kinds." However, Collin criticized their efforts, concluding, "They don't make an effort."

title: South African floods kill at least 300 people
content:
On Wednesday, heavy rains and subsequent flooding in a province on South Africa's eastern coast, including the major port city of Durban, were confirmed to have claimed over 300 lives.

The flooding hampered rescue operations, although some helicopters and personnel were deployed, as stated by General Rudzani Maphwanya. Efforts are underway to restore electricity to the affected areas.

President [Name] remarked, "This disaster is indicative of climate change. It is a stark reminder that climate change is real and serious... We can no longer defer the actions we need to take to address climate change."

Durban suffered significant damage, with Mayor Mxolisi Kaunda noting the challenges in accessing power and water facilities. Sipho Hlomuka, from the Executive Council for Co-operative Governance and Traditional Affairs in KwaZulu-Natal, reported that "The heavy rains have disrupted power lines across many municipalities, and technical teams are working tirelessly to restore power."

title: Motion on transgender women in sports defeated in Queensland Parliament
content:
In Queensland, Australia, a motion put forth by the Katter's Australian Party (KAP) seeking to prohibit transgender women from participating in women's sports was rejected on Wednesday. The motion argued that allowing transgender women to compete would "erode the integrity of female sport."

The KAP's motion asserted that those who support the participation of transgender women in women's sports, regardless of age or level of competition, are complicit in undermining both female athletics and women's rights. It claimed that transgender women possess "insurmountable physical advantages" that create an unfair competitive edge and safety risks for cisgender female athletes.

The proposal was ultimately defeated by a vote of 49 to 33, with backing from the KAP and the Liberal National Party (LNP), but opposed by the ruling government and other parties.

KAP leader Bob Katter emphasized the significance of the issue for parents, mentioning, "As a parent of young girls who will hopefully participate in sports, the thought of them at 15 or 17 years old competing against someone identifying as female does not sit well with me." He acknowledged that while he does not wish to exclude anyone from sports, he believes there is a clear advantage for transgender women in competitive settings.
