title: Indian steel giant stops business with Russia
content:
On Wednesday, Tata Steel, the Indian steel giant, announced the termination of all business ties with Russia, becoming the latest multinational corporation to withdraw operations from the country in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

A spokesperson from Tata Steel's European division stated that the company “does not have any operations or employees in Russia.” The firm also emphasized that its steel manufacturing facilities in India, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have secured alternative sources for raw materials, effectively ending their reliance on Russian supplies.

This announcement positions Tata Steel among a handful of Indian companies to cease business activities in Russia. Last week, India's second-largest information technology firm also revealed that it had halted operations in the country.

Meanwhile, the Indian government has maintained a neutral stance regarding the Russian invasion, facing pressure from various global entities to take a firmer position.

title: China issues preliminary report on China Eastern flight 5735
content:
On Wednesday, the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) released a preliminary report on the crash of China Eastern Airlines Flight MU5735, which resulted in the tragic loss of 132 passengers and crew members. The report did not draw any definitive conclusions regarding the cause of the accident.

The CAAC noted that both of the recovered flight recorders were severely damaged and did not provide any usable information. The recorders have been sent to the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington, D.C. for further analysis.

Flight MU5735 was making a domestic journey from Kunming to Guangzhou when it unexpectedly entered a steep descent and crashed into a mountainside on March 21. The CAAC indicated that air traffic control had its last communication with the pilots at 2:16 PM, while the aircraft was still at cruising altitude.

title: Indian capital New Delhi reports surge in COVID-19 cases
content:
On Wednesday, the Delhi Disaster Management Authority (DDMA) implemented a mask mandate as COVID-19 cases rose sharply in the capital city. Authorities have announced that individuals found violating this mandate will face a fine of ₹500. Delhi's Lieutenant Governor took to Twitter, urging citizens to "ensure strict enforcement of COVID-appropriate behavior."

On Tuesday, Delhi recorded a 26% increase in COVID-19 cases compared to the previous day. On Wednesday, India reported 2,067 new COVID-19 cases, with Delhi accounting for 30% of the total. The city's positivity rate surged from 4.42% to 5.70%. After experiencing a third wave of the pandemic since January, India had been witnessing a decline in daily infections.

Delhi, along with several other states including Kerala, Haryana, Maharashtra, and Uttar Pradesh, has seen a resurgence in COVID-19 cases in recent weeks. India's Union Health Secretary has cautioned states against complacency, stating that it could undermine their pandemic management efforts. Additionally, states have been directed to monitor infection clusters and enhance genome sequencing efforts.

title: Flight recorder for fatal China Eastern flight 5735 crash found
content:
A portion of the wreckage from the downed China Eastern Airlines flight has been located, aviation officials announced on Wednesday.

Flight MU5735 crashed on Monday in southern China, carrying 123 passengers and nine crew members.

Mao Yanfeng of the Civil Aviation Administration of China stated that it is still unclear whether the recovered device is the flight data recorder or the cockpit voice recorder. Authorities are continuing the search for the second recorder, and the integrity of the data remains undetermined.

The aircraft, a Boeing model, had a clean maintenance history. Air traffic controllers maintained standard communications with the flight until it suddenly entered a steep descent. Unfortunately, rescue workers have not found any survivors from the crash, which occurred in a mountainous area near Wuzhou.

As part of the investigation, the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board has appointed a senior investigator to collaborate with the Chinese-led team, a standard practice in incidents involving U.S.-built aircraft. Additionally, technical advisors from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration, Boeing, and other relevant organizations will also participate in the investigation.

title: Former US Secretary of State Albright dies aged 84
content:
Former United States Secretary of State Madeleine Albright passed away at the age of 84 after a battle with cancer, according to a statement released by her family on Wednesday.

Albright made history as the first female US Secretary of State, serving from 1997 to 2001 under President Bill Clinton. Prior to this role, she held the position of US Ambassador to the United Nations from 1993 to 1997.

In tribute to her legacy, President Joe Biden ordered that flags at the White House and all federal buildings be flown at half-staff. He reflected on Albright's steadfast belief that "America is the indispensable nation," adding, "As the world redefined itself in the wake of the Cold War, we were partners and friends working to welcome newly liberated democracies."

Bill and Hillary Clinton commemorated her impact with a joint statement, highlighting her early life in war-torn Europe: "As a child, Madeleine and her family were twice forced to flee their home [...] When the end of the Cold War ushered in a new era of global interdependence, she became America's voice at the UN and then took the helm at the State Department, where she was a passionate advocate for freedom, democracy, and human rights."

Former President George W. Bush praised her understanding of the vital role free societies play in maintaining peace globally.

Madeleine Albright was born Marie Jana Korbelová in 1937 in Prague, then part of Czechoslovakia. Her family fled to exile in 1939 following the German occupation and ultimately arrived in the United States in 1948.

title: India grants Novavax Covid-19 vaccine emergency use authorisation for teens
content:
On Tuesday, the Drug Controller General of India (DCGI) granted emergency use authorization for the Covid-19 vaccine known as NVX-CoV2373, allowing its use for teenagers aged 12 to 17.

Manufactured by the Serum Institute of India under the brand name Covovax, the vaccine demonstrated an efficacy rate of 80% in a late-stage trial conducted on 2,247 Indian teenagers within the age group. This trial took place last month.

In addition to the trials in India, Novavax also completed phase three studies on Covovax in the United States and the United Kingdom, which reported efficacy rates of 90.4% and 89.7%, respectively, among participants aged 18 and older.

Covovax stands out as the first coronavirus vaccine approved in India for this age category. Just last week, India began vaccinating adolescents aged 12 to 14 using the same vaccine.

Stanley C. Erck, President of Novavax, expressed pride in the approval, stating, "We’re proud of this first approval in adolescents given the efficacy and safety that our data show in this population." Meanwhile, the CEO of the Serum Institute of India remarked that this development "marks another significant milestone in strengthening our immunization efforts."

In December of last year, the DCGI had given the green light for Covovax to be administered to adults over 18 in India. The vaccine is also listed for emergency use by the World Health Organization and has received authorization in countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines, and Bangladesh.

title: Attack at Texas elementary school kills at least 19, including 18 children
content:
On Tuesday, a tragic attack at a school in Uvalde, Texas, claimed the lives of at least 18 young children and one staff member. Reports indicate that the number of staff fatalities may range from one to three, leading to some confusion regarding the exact count.

The suspected gunman, identified by Governor Greg Abbott as 18-year-old Salvador Ramos, allegedly shot his grandmother before heading to the school. After abandoning his vehicle nearby, Ramos entered the building armed with a handgun and possibly a rifle. Both local authorities and NPR have reported that Ramos was killed by responding police officers.

Uvalde, a small community located about 80 miles west of San Antonio and near the Mexican border, has a population that is approximately 70% Hispanic or Latin American, according to U.S. Census data. The town has around 16,000 residents.

This incident marks the deadliest school shooting in Texas history and is the most devastating attack on an elementary school in the United States since the Sandy Hook tragedy in Newtown, Connecticut, in 2012, which resulted in the deaths of 20 children and six faculty members. The Sandy Hook shooting sparked national discussions about gun rights and gun control, issues that are likely to resurface in the wake of this latest tragedy.

title: Russia launches full-scale invasion against Ukraine
content:
**Headline:** Russian Troops Launch Invasion of Ukraine as Tensions Escalate

Russian troops initiated an invasion of Ukraine on February 24, 2022, firing missiles at several cities, including Kyiv, Kharkiv, Donetsk, and Odesa. 

In a televised address, Russian President Vladimir Putin characterized the offensive as a "special military operation," claiming its purpose is the "demilitarization and de-nazification of Ukraine." The operation began at 06:00 Moscow time (03:00 UTC). Following the announcement, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky declared martial law across the nation.

Witnesses reported explosions from missile strikes in major cities and gunfire near Kyiv's main airport, accompanied by air raid sirens throughout the capital.

Putin asserted that Russia felt compelled to defend itself against threats it claims were emanating from Ukraine, in response to a plea for assistance from regions in eastern Ukraine seeking to curb alleged Ukrainian aggression—a claim the United States has dismissed as Russian propaganda.

On February 21, Russia recognized the self-proclaimed Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics in eastern Ukraine as independent states and subsequently entered into agreements of friendship, cooperation, and assistance with these regions.

United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres urged Putin to halt military actions "in the name of humanity" following the announcement of the operation.

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowed that the West would respond decisively, condemning Putin's actions as a "path of bloodshed and destruction." British Defense Secretary Ben Wallace and Foreign Secretary Liz Truss expressed strong opposition to the invasion, with Truss asserting that "nothing is off the table" in terms of actions to counter Putin.

U.S. President Joe Biden condemned the assault as "unprovoked and unjustified," announcing plans to meet with G7 leaders to discuss a coordinated response, with significant sanctions on Russia expected.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen also condemned the invasion as "unjustified," emphasizing the need for accountability for Moscow.

A spokesperson for the Chinese Foreign Ministry called for all parties to prioritize peace rather than escalate tensions, criticizing those who condemned others without engaging in meaningful dialogue.

NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg denounced Russia's "reckless and unprovoked attack" on Ukraine, announcing that NATO allies would convene to address the repercussions of Moscow's aggressive actions.

title: Cowboys for Trump founder convicted of entering U.S. Capitol illegally during January 6 attacks
content:
On Tuesday, a federal judge in the United States found Couy Griffin, a commissioner from New Mexico, guilty of entering a restricted area, specifically the U.S. Capitol building. In the same ruling, he was acquitted of a disorderly conduct charge.

Griffin is among hundreds of individuals charged with crimes related to the events of January 6, 2021, when Congress and then-Vice President Mike Pence were in the process of certifying the results of the November 2020 presidential election. This trial marks the second related to these events and is the first bench trial.

As a founding member of Cowboys for Trump, Griffin faced charges of entering a restricted area and disorderly conduct. Prosecutors, led by Senior Assistant U.S. Attorney Janani Iyengar, argued that Griffin climbed over a wall and a temporary staircase to gain access to the Capitol. The judge noted, "All of this would suggest to a normal person that perhaps you should not be entering the area." The prosecution's case was supported by video evidence and testimony from another participant in the Capitol breach.

The judge also stated that Griffin was not seen engaging in property destruction or physical violence, which were prevalent among the crowd during the siege. He emphasized that Griffin’s statements on that day did not explicitly incite others to commit acts of violence, categorizing them as free speech rather than disorderly conduct.

Griffin’s defense team contended that there were no signs indicating that entry was prohibited at the Capitol.

In his ruling, Judge McFadden highlighted that the Capitol was designated a restricted area on January 6 because it was being safeguarded by law enforcement officers protecting Vice President Pence. The defense argued that since Pence had been evacuated to a secure underground location, the Capitol itself should not have been considered restricted at the time of Griffin’s presence. This trial marks the first time that details regarding Pence's location during the attack have been disclosed to the public.

Griffin is the first of the January 6 defendants to undergo a bench trial, in which a judge makes the ruling without a jury. The only other defendant to stand trial so far, Guy Reffitt, was convicted on five counts by a jury earlier this month.

After the court proceedings, Griffin stated to the media, "I wear January 6 like a badge of honor," alleging that the U.S. government had entrapped those who stormed the Capitol. He is scheduled for sentencing on June 17, 2022.

Judge McFadden was appointed to the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia in 2017 by then-President Donald Trump.

On January 6, 2021, a large group of protesters gathered in Washington, D.C., for a rally supporting then-President Trump, who had falsely claimed that the 2020 election was stolen from him. During his address to the crowd, Trump encouraged attendees to march to the Capitol, though he did not call for violence. Subsequently, many protesters breached the Capitol, causing extensive property damage and resulting in the deaths of five individuals during the chaos.

title: Australian government pays A$20m for copyright to Aboriginal flag
content:
On Tuesday, just ahead of Australia Day, the Australian government announced it has acquired the copyright for the Aboriginal Flag for AU$20.05 million.

Created by Harold Thomas in 1970, the flag symbolizes the deep connection of Aboriginal people to the land. Although it was officially adopted as a national flag in 1995, the copyright remained with Thomas, meaning its use required his approval or compensation.

Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that the flag would now be treated similarly to the Australian national flag, allowing anyone to use it as long as it is displayed "respectfully and dignifiedly."

Morrison emphasized, "All Australians can now display the Aboriginal Flag on apparel such as sports jerseys and shirts; it can be painted on sports grounds, featured on websites, included in artworks, and used in any medium without needing permission or incurring fees. We’ve freed the Aboriginal Flag for Australians."

Indigenous Affairs Minister said: "For the past 50 years, we have embraced Harold Thomas’ artwork as our own — we have marched under the Aboriginal Flag, stood behind it, and proudly flown it."

"Now that the government holds the copyright, it belongs to everyone, and it can never be taken away."

Concerns regarding the commercial arrangements surrounding the flag were highlighted in 2019 when WAM Clothing, a licensed clothing company, issued notices to the NRL and AFL, claiming that jerseys worn during their Indigenous rounds infringed its copyright. At that time, Wyatt encouraged fans to express their discontent by wearing the flag.

Under the agreement, the government paid AU$20.05 million to Thomas and other license holders to secure the copyright and reclaim the rights held by licensees. The government plans to:
- Allocate future royalties from commercial flag sales to support Indigenous initiatives,
- Establish a AU$100,000 scholarship in Thomas' honor for Indigenous students to develop leadership skills,
- Accept and display a painting by Thomas that celebrates the flag's 50th anniversary and the transfer of copyright,
- Create a web portal dedicated to the flag’s history and educational resources.

Aboriginal woman Geraldine Atkinson expressed her delight at the government acquiring the flag, calling it a reason for Indigenous Australians to celebrate on Australia Day. "When I read the news, I couldn't contain my excitement. We're not celebrating the day, but rather our flag and what it represents," she said.

While Senator welcomed the news, she expressed caution regarding the ownership of the copyright. "I’m concerned about the implications of the Commonwealth owning the copyright for our flag and what it means for our people’s self-determination," she remarked. "We must engage in genuine discussions about the ramifications of this decision and whether alternative models of community ownership were thoroughly explored. Currently, this feels like a win."

Senator also stated her intention to scrutinize the deal closely during the Senate's upcoming budget estimates, saying, "I look forward to investigating this deal and reviewing its details, especially concerning copyright and custodianship of the flag." McCarthy added, "Scott Morrison and the Indigenous Affairs Minister need to clarify the funding sources for this deal."

title: Chinese Foreign Minister visits India amid recent standoff in Ladakh
content:
**Revised News Report:**

On Thursday, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi engaged in bilateral talks with Indian External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar and National Security Advisor Ajit Doval in New Delhi. Wang's visit followed trips to Pakistan and Afghanistan, highlighting regional diplomatic efforts.

During the discussions, the ministers addressed the recent border clashes, which resulted in the deaths of twenty Indian soldiers and four Chinese soldiers. Wang expressed a desire to ease the strained relations between the two nations.

Jaishankar emphasized that full demilitarization of the border is essential for restoring normal relations with China. He pointed out that "the frictions and tensions stemming from China's military deployments since April 2020 cannot coexist with a constructive relationship between the two neighbors."

Doval added his voice to the call for de-escalation at the border, noting that prior talks among military commanders have failed to yield solutions. Both nations currently maintain a significant buildup of troops and military equipment along the border.

The ministers also discussed the ongoing situation in Ukraine, both calling for an immediate ceasefire. India and China, which have strong bilateral ties with Russia, have yet to publicly denounce Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Notably, Wang's arrival in India was shrouded in secrecy, with no official notifications issued by either government. He departed for Nepal late Friday as part of China's initiative to strengthen ties with neighboring countries.

Earlier, India had criticized comments made by Wang Yi regarding the situation in Kashmir during a summit held in Pakistan.

title: G7 leaders warn Russia on unconventional weapons
content:
During a summit held on Thursday in Brussels, Belgium, leaders of the Group of Seven (G7) issued a strong warning to Russia regarding the potential use of biological, chemical, or nuclear weapons in its ongoing invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24.

The statement emphasized: "We warn against any threats involving the use of chemical, biological, or nuclear weapons or related materials. We remind Russia of its obligations under international treaties to which it is a signatory, which safeguard us all."

The leaders expressed their unwavering support for the Ukrainian people, stating: "We are steadfast in our commitment to the heroic resistance of Ukraine against Russia's unjustifiable and illegal aggression. We will enhance our support for Ukraine and its neighboring countries."

Additionally, the G7 urged Russia to adhere to a ceasefire order issued on March 9 and halt its military operations in Ukraine.

title: Loyalists suspected of threatening Irish Foreign Minister with fake bomb
content:
**Revised News Article:**

Government and police sources suspect the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) may be responsible for a bomb threat directed at Ireland's Minister for Foreign Affairs during an event in Belfast, Northern Ireland, yesterday.

Last night, Assistant Chief Constable Mark McEwan of the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) revealed that a "primary line of investigation" points to the paramilitary group behind what he termed "disgraceful actions." This threat interrupted Minister Simon Coveney's speech at the Building Common Ground peace-building event, forcing the evacuation of over twenty-five homes in the vicinity.

According to police, a white van was hijacked around 9:00 a.m. The driver, whose family was allegedly threatened by two armed assailants, was compelled to transport what he believed were explosives. He first drove to a nearby street, where the device was loaded into the vehicle, before heading to the Holy Cross Chapel adjacent to the Houben Centre where Coveney was speaking.

Coveney was reportedly just minutes into his address when security personnel informed him of the bomb threat, leading to his swift evacuation to a "secure location" by PSNI officers.

Witness Sarah McKinley described the hijacked driver as a "workman clutching a toolbag" who appeared distraught outside the venue, apologizing to guests after relaying his ordeal to security. She noted that he was "completely shellshocked" and revealed that he had been forced into driving the van.

McEwan confirmed that the driver is receiving treatment in hospital, though he did not disclose the specifics of his condition. "Just think about this: the victim believed he was driving a van containing a live bomb, while his family was under threat," McEwan said.

He added that a security threat persists in Northern Ireland, warning that "an attack is likely." However, he did not clarify whether the weapons used to threaten the driver were real, only noting that the situation felt genuine at the time. It remains unclear if Coveney was specifically targeted or if he requires enhanced security, especially given previous loyalist graffiti depicting him alongside Taoiseach Leo Varadkar.

A source indicated that loyalists hold Coveney and Varadkar responsible for feelings of being undermined due to the contentious post-Brexit Northern Ireland Protocol. It is believed the bomb threat was a premeditated response linked to these sentiments.

This incident comes shortly after the United Kingdom's counter-intelligence agency, MI5, downgraded its terrorist threat level in Northern Ireland from "severe" to "substantial" on Tuesday. Secretary of State for Northern Ireland Chris Heaton-Harris stated this change reflects "the significant progress that Northern Ireland has made towards a more peaceful, prosperous, and safer society." However, he emphasized the need for continued vigilance against the "minority" that threatens this peace.

Politicians across Ireland and the UK have condemned the attack. Coveney expressed his "sadness and frustration" that an individual had been victimized and targeted in this manner, referring to the driver. He characterized the hijacker as part of the "small minority willing to use violence to advance their aims."

Tim Attwood, the leader of the Northern Irish Foundation involved in the event, labeled the attack as an "attempt to drag us back" and reiterated the organization's commitment to promoting peace and reconciliation. "A suspect device will not stop the work of the John and Pat Hume Foundation," he assured.

The bomb threat led to disruptions at local schools and a nursing home and even forced the cancellation of a funeral. Priest Gary Donegan remarked on the mindless nature of the actions taken, saying, "Forget about the actual event itself; there’s a family grieving who now couldn’t even have a funeral." McEwan condemned the incident as "clearly designed to cause maximum disruption to the local community."

title: U.S. government task force moves to alter place names containing racial slur
content:
On Tuesday, officials from the United States federal government announced their intention to rename hundreds of locations on federal land that contain an anti-Native American slur. Each site will be presented with five potential replacement names, and the government is set to hold virtual discussions with Native American groups before making recommendations to the Board on Geographic Names later this year.

The Derogatory Names Task Force, consisting of 13 members from various federal agencies, including the Bureau of Land Management, is spearheading this initiative. 

The term in question, rooted in a word for "woman," has evolved over time into a derogatory term for Native American and First Nations women. U.S. Secretary of the Interior Deb Haaland designated the term as derogatory last November.

"Considering these replacement names marks a significant step forward in our commitment to eliminating outdated derogatory terms," said Haaland, the first Native American to hold a position in the U.S. Cabinet. "Throughout this process, we will prioritize engagement with tribes, stakeholders, and the public to promote equity and inclusion."

The affected geographic sites are spread across Arizona, New Mexico, Nevada, Idaho, California, and seven other states. This initiative is part of a broader movement to remove the offensive term from place names. Recently, a ski resort near the California-Nevada border rebranded itself as "Palisades Tahoe," a decision praised by local advocates. "The term serves as a constant reminder of the injustices faced by Native people, particularly the Washoe," remarked Darrel Cruz of the Washoe Tribe Historic Preservation Office last summer. "It reflects a painful history inflicted upon us, and we reject it."

The task force invites public feedback, which can be submitted via mail or through the website Regulations.gov.

title: US President Biden says Russian President Putin must be ousted
content:
In a speech delivered in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, U.S. President Joe Biden stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin "cannot remain in power" following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Biden emphasized the importance of clarity in the ongoing conflict, warning that "this battle will not be won in days or months."

Biden's remarks deviated from previous U.S. statements, prompting White House officials to clarify that the President was not calling for regime change in Russia. An administration source explained to Fox News, "The President's point was that Putin cannot be allowed to exert power over his neighbors or the region. He was not discussing Putin’s power within Russia."

In addition to his remarks about Putin, Biden issued a stern warning to Russia regarding NATO. "Don't even think about moving one single inch of NATO territory," he declared, affirming the U.S. commitment to defend every part of NATO under Article Five with full force.

Addressing the Russian populace, Biden said, "This is not the future you deserve for your families and children," adding, "I'm telling you the truth: this war is not worthy of you, the Russian people." To Ukrainians, he emphasized solidarity, stating, "We stand with you. Period."

In response, a representative from the Kremlin remarked, "This is not a decision to be made by Mr. Biden. It is a choice that should be left to the people of the Russian Federation."

title: Macron defeats Le Pen in French presidential runoff election
content:
On Monday, Emmanuel Macron was declared the winner of the presidential runoff, defeating Marine Le Pen by securing 58.54% of the votes. The two candidates had previously squared off in the first round.

Macron's margin of victory and that of his party was narrower than in 2017, marking the strongest performance to date for the far-right National Rally party.

In his victory speech, Macron acknowledged that many voters chose him not necessarily in support of his policies, but to prevent a far-right government. "I want to thank them, and I recognize I owe them a responsibility in the years to come. We must be benevolent and respectful, as our country is filled with so many doubts and divisions," he stated.

Le Pen, in her concession speech, expressed her disappointment but emphasized that "a great wind of freedom could have blown over our country, but the ballot box decided otherwise. The game is not quite over," she added.

Looking ahead, France is set to hold parliamentary elections in June.

title: International Labour Organization elects first African leader as director general
content:
On Friday, the International Labour Organization (ILO) elected former Togo Prime Minister Gilbert Houngbo as its next director-general, marking the first time an African has held the position since the organization's inception in 1919.

The election was conducted via secret ballot by the ILO's 56-member governing body, with Houngbo, 61, securing his victory in the second round with 30 votes. His closest competitor, former French Minister of Labor Muriel Pénicaud, garnered 23 votes, while former South Korean Foreign Minister Kang Kyung-wha received two votes and South African businessman Mthunzi Mdwaba received one. Australian Greg Vines, the current deputy director-general, was eliminated in the first round of voting.

The governing body of the ILO consists of government, employee, and employer representatives from its 187 member states. It plays a critical role in shaping the ILO's policies, setting its agenda, and electing the director-general.

Previously, Houngbo served as the ILO's deputy director-general from 2013 to 2017 and is currently the President of the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). He will officially take over as director-general on October 1, 2022.

title: Russia continues to attack Ukraine amid sanctions from the west
content:
**Title: Suspected Russian Missile Strike Targets Kyiv Oil Terminal Amid Escalating Conflict**

On Sunday, a suspected Russian missile strike hit a civilian oil terminal near Kyiv, Ukraine, as reported by Ukrainian Member of Parliament Anna Purtova. She characterized the attack as an "environmental catastrophe" due to the facility's proximity to the capital.

In conjunction with this incident, Russian troops were spotted in various locations in and around Kharkiv, where a gas pipeline was reportedly destroyed before dawn. Local authorities advised residents to remain indoors, citing incursions by Russian light vehicles into Kharkiv, including the city center.

Additionally, on Saturday, Russian forces launched a missile strike on a high-rise residential building in Kyiv, resulting in injuries to at least six individuals.

In diplomatic efforts, Ukraine initially rejected a proposal from the Russian government to hold talks in Belarus. President Volodymyr Zelensky stated that Belarus was complicit in the invasion and expressed a preference for negotiations to take place elsewhere. However, today Ukraine has agreed to meet with the Russian Federation at the Belarusian border, following a call from Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko to Zelensky earlier Sunday.

The United States and its allies have ramped up military support for Ukraine and imposed extensive sanctions on Russia. On Saturday, it was announced that several Russian banks would be disconnected from the SWIFT banking system, severing their access to international financial transactions. Additionally, measures will be taken against the Russian government to prevent it from circumventing the effects of these sanctions.

In a joint statement, the leaders of the European Commission and the United States pledged to hold Russia accountable, asserting their commitment to ensuring that the war becomes a strategic failure for President Putin.

Tech giants Google and Facebook have also moved to prohibit the Russian state-controlled media outlet from generating revenue through advertisements.

Meanwhile, the Kremlin announced that Russian troops were advancing "in all directions," with President Putin expressing gratitude to the forces engaged in operations in Ukraine. Reports indicate that Putin has ordered his military to maintain a high level of readiness, citing “aggressive statements” from NATO and stringent financial sanctions imposed by the West and its allies. According to Ukrainian presidential advisor Mykhaylo Podolyak, over 3,500 Russian troops have been reported killed or wounded, although Russia has not disclosed any casualty figures.

title: Second data recorder is found for China Eastern flight 5735
content:
On Sunday, rescue workers recovered the flight data recorder from China Eastern Airlines in China, following officials' confirmation the previous evening that there were no survivors from the March 21 crash.

The flight data recorder, one of two "black boxes," was located under the surface in a mountainous region at 9:20 AM local time (1:20 AM UTC). The second black box was recovered earlier on Wednesday. Both devices are currently being analyzed by the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) in Beijing.

The MU5735 flight crashed last Monday, roughly one hour into its domestic journey from Kunming to Guangzhou, with 132 people aboard, including 123 passengers and nine crew members. For reasons still unknown, the Boeing aircraft went into a nosedive, losing significant altitude in a matter of seconds, while the pilots remained unresponsive to air traffic control. The violent impact created a crater 20 meters (65.6 feet) wide and scattered debris over a large area.

Late Saturday evening, aviation officials announced that there were no survivors. To date, 120 victims have been identified through analysis, and crews are continuing to recover identification documents and bank cards from the wreckage. CAAC deputy director-general Hu Zhenjiang noted that the search for remains will persist.

Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for a thorough investigation, which will be led by the CAAC with assistance from the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board and Boeing.

On Sunday afternoon, rescue workers, police, and soldiers observed three minutes of silence in remembrance of the victims, bowing their heads and removing their hats and helmets.

As a precaution, China Eastern and its subsidiary airlines have temporarily grounded all of their 737-800 aircraft, although they do not suspect any faults with the aircraft.

title: Ukraine says it recaptured lost ground in war with Russia
content:
Reports emerging yesterday indicate that Ukraine has successfully recaptured territory, including the suburb of Irpin, near the capital city Kyiv, from advancing Russian forces ahead of scheduled peace talks in Istanbul, Turkey, later today.

Irpin's mayor, Alexandar Markushin, announced, "We have good news today — Irpin has been liberated," but cautioned residents who had evacuated that it was too early to return due to ongoing fighting.

Additionally, a senior United States defense official, speaking anonymously to the Associated Press, confirmed that territories in the northeast of Ukraine, near the Russian border, are also back under Ukrainian control.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy revealed that Russia has proposed a guarantee of neutrality and a ban on NATO membership as terms for peace. Despite this, Zelenskyy conveyed to the nation in a broadcast yesterday evening: "We still have to fight, we must endure. We can’t express our emotions now. We cannot raise expectations, simply to avoid burnout."

He emphasized that "Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity are beyond doubt" and hinted at a willingness to discuss the status of semi-autonomous areas in the region.

Negotiations are set to take place on Tuesday in Istanbul between representatives from both nations; however, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov remarked yesterday that immediate meetings would be counterproductive. He suggested that a meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Zelenskyy should occur when the two sides are closer to reaching an agreement.

title: Italian President Sergio Mattarella re-elected for second term, ending successor row
content:
Italy's incumbent President, Sergio Mattarella, was re-elected for a second seven-year term on Wednesday, after an eighth round of voting to find a successor proved unsuccessful.

At 80 years old, Mattarella had previously indicated his intention to step down, even going so far as to rent an apartment in Rome in preparation for his departure from the presidential palace at Quirinale. However, he ultimately decided to remain in office due to significant pressure from leading political figures, including Prime Minister Mario Draghi, who emphasized the need for stability in the Republic. Mattarella's first term was set to end on February 3.

During discussions at Quirinale, parliamentarians urging him to stay reported Mattarella stating, "I had other plans, but if needed, I am at your disposal." The process of selecting a successor involved an electoral college of 1,009 "grand electors," consisting of 321 Senators, 630 Members of Parliament, and 58 regional representatives, resulting in seven rounds of voting without a consensus candidate.

Reuters noted that the failure of Parliament to unite behind a compromise candidate reflected "deep scars, with potentially dangerous repercussions for political stability" in Italy. There was an enthusiastic response in the Chamber of Deputies when Mattarella exceeded the two-thirds majority requirement for re-election, securing a total of 759 votes.

Statements from party leaders following the vote largely supported Mattarella's continued presidency. Matteo Salvini, leader of the anti-migrant League party, said, "Italians don't deserve further days of confusion," advocating for “President Mattarella at Quirinale and Draghi at the government.” Draghi, who was also considered a candidate for the presidency, described the outcome as "splendid news for Italians" and expressed gratitude to Mattarella for complying with the strong will of Parliament.

Despite general agreement from many political leaders, Giorgia Meloni, leader of the far-right Brothers of Italy party, sharply criticized the decision, stating that "Parliament has shown it is not fit for Italians." Meloni accused her allies of "bartering away" the presidency and called for a reevaluation of their coalition. She also expressed surprise that Mattarella would accept re-election after previously rejecting the idea, advocating instead for Draghi to assume the role, which could create a vacancy in the Prime Minister position and potentially lead to early elections.

Giuseppe Conte, leader of Italy's largest populist party, endorsed Mattarella, describing him as "the guarantor of everybody, impartial and authoritative." Conte had resigned as Prime Minister in 2021 over his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Though primarily a ceremonial role, the President holds significant powers, including appointing the Prime Minister and dissolving Parliament, which can be crucial during political crises. This situation arises amid significant fragmentation in Italian politics, where governments often last only a year due to instability.

Mattarella has been praised for navigating Italy out of a brief political crisis by appointing a broad coalition government led by Draghi, an independent who previously served as the President of the European Central Bank. According to Wolfango Piccoli from the advisory firm Teneo, the political landscape has grown less favorable for Draghi's administration, which faces substantial challenges in the remaining year of its term.

Critics argue that the choice to re-elect a reluctant incumbent reflects Italy's political divisions. There have been calls for the election of the country's first female president or someone younger, highlighting a perceived lack of innovation among MPs. Despite the lack of alternative candidates, support for Mattarella remained a rare point of consensus among lawmakers, as noted by Forza Italia national coordinator, who spoke in a BBC interview.

Mattarella, viewed as a traditional and unassuming leader, was first elected in 2015. He has held various governmental roles throughout his career, including Minister of Education, Minister of Defense, and Judge of the Constitutional Court, along with two decades as a Member of Parliament. His family has a long history in politics; his father was a founder of the Christian Democracy party, and his brother, who was President of Sicily, was assassinated in 1980.

Potential candidates mentioned by Agence France-Presse prior to the vote included former Prime Ministers Romano Prodi and Matteo Renzi, along with former Chamber of Deputies President Laura Boldrini. Female candidates considered were current and former ministers and the President of the Senate.

title: James Webb Space Telescope moves to final orbit
content:
On Monday, the James Webb Space Telescope successfully entered its designated orbit around the L2 Lagrange point, situated approximately one million miles from Earth, on the opposite side from our planet. 

A final maneuver concluded the spacecraft's month-long journey, which began in late December amid years of delays and budget overruns. Over its expected five-to-ten-year mission, the telescope will focus on studying the most distant galaxies, providing insights into the universe's earliest formations following the Big Bang.

During its journey, referred to as "30 days of terror," the telescope successfully deployed its 21-foot (6.4 meter) wide mirror, unfurled its solar panels, and cooled to temperatures below 50 degrees Fahrenheit at the L2 point. 

The L2 location is an advantageous site for spacecraft, where the gravitational forces of the Sun and Earth are balanced. Full scientific operations are scheduled to commence later this year, involving 13 teams of scientists. The primary objective of this mission is to identify the most distant and earliest galaxies formed after the Big Bang, thereby contributing to our understanding of the universe's origins. The nominal mission duration is five years, with a potential extension to ten years. Unlike its predecessor, the Hubble Space Telescope, which operates much closer to Earth, the James Webb's instruments will face away from the Sun, enhancing the clarity of its observational data.

The James Webb Space Telescope was launched aboard an Ariane 5 rocket on December 25 from the Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana, after reaching the site in October. The launch date was pushed back by a week due to adverse weather conditions.

The project was initiated by the United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) in 1996, originally aiming for a launch in 2007 at a budget of $550 million. After contracting Northrop Grumman to construct the telescope, mission managers projected that a 2010 launch would cost between $1 billion and $3.5 billion. However, redesigns to mitigate technical challenges delayed the launch to 2013 with an updated budget of $4.5 billion. A project review ordered by Congress in 2010 further postponed the launch to 2015.

In 2011, the proposed cancellation of the project, estimated to eventually cost $6.5 billion, was tabled. Following a revised plan for a 2018 launch at an anticipated budget of $8.8 billion, additional technical issues and the COVID-19 pandemic pushed the launch to 2021.

title: North Korean veteran statesman Ri Yong Mu dies aged 97
content:
A North Korean state-run newspaper reported yesterday that high-ranking political and military official Ri Yong-mu passed away on Thursday morning at the age of 97.

Ri served in various key roles, including positions in the State Inspection Commission, the Traffic Commission, and the General Political Bureau of the Korean People's Army (KPA). Notably, he held the position of vice-chairman for nearly 20 years, according to the Rodong Sinmun.

The paper described Ri as a "revolutionary soldier loyal to President Kim Il-sung, Chairman Kim Jong-il, and a veteran revolutionary who led a meaningful life under the esteemed guidance of Comrade Kim Jong-un." The article emphasized his contributions as "feats performed with total dedication to the Party and the state that will be remembered fondly by our people and the officers and men of the People's Army."

State-run radio, Voice of Korea, reported that current leader Kim Jong-un visited Ri's grave to express "deep condolences on the occasion of his passing." Senior Party and KPA officials accompanied Kim during the visit. The station referred to Ri as "a cherished revolutionary comrade who dedicated his efforts to strengthening and developing the Party, state, and revolutionary armed forces until the very end of his life."

An earlier report noted that Ri Yong-mu was awarded the Order of Kim Il-sung in 1992 and the Order of the National Flag in 2012, along with the prestigious honorary title of Hero of the Republic.

title: BBC apologises after 'Manchester United are rubbish' appears on news ticker
content:
The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) issued an apology on Tuesday following the appearance of the phrase "Manchester United are rubbish" on a live ticker during a tennis update. Presenter Annita McVeigh explained that the inappropriate comment was the result of a trainee's experiment with the ticker. "They were just writing random things, not in earnest, and that comment appeared," she said. McVeigh also expressed regret for any offense caused to Manchester United fans, stating, "Apologies if you saw that and were offended."

The BBC confirmed in a statement that a "technical glitch during training with our test ticker" led to the inappropriate phrase rolling over into live programming for a brief moment. The organization apologized for any upset it may have caused.

In a lighthearted response, another BBC presenter and supporter of rival club Manchester City tweeted, "I had nothing to do with this!!"

This incident comes in the wake of Manchester City securing a recent victory, while Manchester United finished sixth, marking their lowest points tally in Premier League history. Additionally, the announcement of a new Manchester United manager was made on Monday.

title: India enters second day of a two-day nationwide general strike
content:
Yesterday marked the second day of a nationwide protest in India, organized by a coalition of trade unions and regional groups. Hundreds of demonstrators gathered at a well-known protest site, waving red flags in unison.

The protesters criticized the economic policies of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration, asserting that they were detrimental to the country's working class. Swadesh Dev Roye, a senior official from one of the participating unions, remarked that the government "seeks to obscure its economic misdeeds under the pretense of nationalism and religion."

Among their demands, the protesters called for job security in the unorganized sector, increased wages under the Minimum Wages Act, and the repeal of the Labour Code, which grants employers greater leeway in determining working hours and pay.

Additionally, some protestors voiced their opposition to government plans to privatize two public sector enterprises. The Modi administration has been pursuing the privatization of various state-owned entities with the aim of boosting economic growth.

According to the general secretary of one of the unions, over 20 crore (200 million) individuals participated in the protests on the first day, leading to significant disruptions in banking, market operations, and railway services.

The backdrop of these demonstrations is India's struggle with economic challenges; the country experienced a recession during the initial two years of the COVID-19 pandemic and recorded an unemployment rate of eight percent in December of the previous year.

title: Elon Musk emails tell Tesla employees return to office, or "assume you have resigned"
content:
Leaked emails from Elon Musk to Tesla's executive team, sent on Tuesday and released publicly on Wednesday, reveal Musk's firm directive that employees must work in the office for a minimum of 40 hours per week or leave the company. 

One email, revealed by multiple sources including Reuters, stated: "Anyone who wishes to work remotely must be in the office for a minimum (and I mean *minimum*) of 40 hours per week or depart Tesla. This requirement is less than what we ask of factory workers."

Another email emphasized this policy further, clarifying that "everyone at Tesla is required to spend at least 40 hours in the office per week," and noted that this office "must be where your actual colleagues are located, not some remote pseudo office. If you don’t show up, we will assume you have resigned."

While many companies are considering a rollback of COVID-19 work-from-home policies, Reuters indicates that several major firms in California do not enforce full-time office attendance. Google, for instance, has implemented a hybrid work model where employees are in the office three days a week and work from home for the remaining two.

Musk defended his stance, stating, "There are of course companies that don't require this, but when was the last time they shipped a great new product? It's been a while [...] Tesla has and will create and actually manufacture the most exciting and meaningful products of any company on Earth. This will not happen by phoning it in." He reflected on his own experiences during a production slowdown at Tesla's factory between 2017 and 2018, writing, "If I had not done that, Tesla would long ago have gone bankrupt."

Stephen Knight, executive director of the health advocacy group Worksafe, responded to these developments by pointing out that mandating a full return to the office can lead to COVID-19 outbreaks. He highlighted Tesla's problematic history with worker safety, citing past incidents, including Musk's controversial decision to reopen a factory in Fremont in May 2020 despite local health guidelines. That facility reported 440 COVID-19 cases within seven months of reopening. Musk has also made headlines for praising Chinese workers for their dedication while criticizing the American workforce for attempts to avoid in-office work.

In a recent survey conducted in January, 61% of U.S. adults currently working from home indicated they are doing so by choice, and 77% reported engaging in remote work at least occasionally.

In a contrasting statement from March, Twitter CEO expressed a different perspective on work arrangements, tweeting, "Wherever you feel most productive and creative is where you will work, including from home full-time forever. Office every day? That works too. Some days in the office, some days from home? Of course."

Additionally, Musk's ongoing business dealings have drawn scrutiny. On May 13, he suspended a $44 billion deal to acquire Twitter, referencing a Reuters article from May 2 that estimated the portion of active users that were fake or spam accounts. The rationale behind Musk's decision remains unclear.

title: Ethics chief: UK PM's reforms after Partygate "highly unsatisfactory", won't "restore public trust"
content:
The Chair of the Committee on Standards in Public Life has strongly criticized UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's proposed amendments to the ministerial code following recent controversies, describing the changes as “highly unsatisfactory.”

The watchdog condemned the revisions announced last week, which allow ministers to continue serving even after breaching the code and maintain restrictions on the ethics adviser’s ability to initiate investigations without the Prime Minister’s consent. The Chair, Lord Evans, warned that “suspicion about how the ministerial code is managed will persist” unless the ethics adviser, currently Lord Geidt, is granted greater independence in scrutinizing ministerial conduct.

In a blog post published on Monday, Evans reiterated the Committee's recommendation that breaches of the code should be met with a range of graduated sanctions rather than the previous "all-or-nothing approach" that has caused unease among past prime ministers. However, he noted that the government's proposed reforms still tie investigations to the Prime Minister’s approval while suggesting penalties such as public apologies, fines, or resignation requests.

Johnson dismissed Geidt’s concerns regarding the “legitimate question” of whether receiving a fixed penalty notice for violating Covid-19 restrictions in June 2020 constituted a breach of the code. In a letter on Tuesday, the Prime Minister asserted, “taking account of all the circumstances, I did not breach the code,” claiming he upheld “the principles of leadership and accountability” in clearing the parliamentary record.

Geidt has criticized the “circular process” that could undermine the credibility of the ministerial code, reportedly considering his resignation on Tuesday. He indicated that he had advised Johnson’s team that the Prime Minister should publicly address his obligations under the ministerial code, but his suggestions went unheeded.

Evans supported Geidt’s position, stating, “an adviser who believes their advice will be disregarded will simply choose not to offer it at all, which has already created a precedent for resignations.”

Meanwhile, a wave of Conservative MPs has been submitting letters of no confidence to the party’s 1922 Committee, chaired by Sir Graham Brady. A compilation by the BBC on Wednesday indicated that at least 28 MPs, part of a 54 MP threshold, have publicly called for Johnson's resignation, with others potentially having submitted letters in private. The group includes former ministers, committee chairs, and backbenchers from across the Brexit spectrum.

Among the latest dissenters, MP for Angus, Scotland, stated to constituents, “It beggars belief that while the government was working to support people during the pandemic, a rotten core with an unacceptable culture continued, disregarding the same restrictions placed on the public.”

Another Conservative MP expressed no confidence, emphasizing that although Johnson has asserted that measures for systemic change have been implemented, “until I see real evidence of leadership that listens and adapts, I am not prepared to defend it.”

Ministers have accused rebel Tories of doing "the opposition’s work," with Culture Secretary Nadine Dorries stating that focusing on dissenters is merely a "sideshow" and urging colleagues to "forget it."

Johnson had previously overruled the decision of Geidt's predecessor, Sir Alex Allan, who determined that Priti Patel had "not consistently met the high standards expected of her” in 2020, leading to Sir Alex's resignation. He noted, “It is for the Prime Minister to judge whether a minister's actions amount to a breach of the ministerial code,” but added, “I feel it is right for me to resign now.”

Tim Durrant, associate director for the Institute for Government, commented to The Guardian, “The ongoing issues surrounding behavior and propriety within this government have highlighted the limitations of the code and of Lord Geidt's role.”

title: Scientists discover seagrass off Australia is world's largest plant
content:
Scientists at the University of Western Australia released a study on Wednesday identifying an extensive seagrass meadow off the coast of Western Australia as the world's largest known plant. This remarkable organism is believed to have started cloning itself approximately 4,500 years ago and spans around 200 square kilometers (77 square miles) within Shark Bay, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The bay was submerged relatively recently, within the last 8,500 years.

In their research, the scientists analyzed 18,000 distinct genetic markers from the seagrass in an effort to identify samples for restoration projects. Instead, they were surprised to find that the entire meadow is a single organism that has reproduced clonally many times. Dr. Martin Breed, an ecologist at Flinders University, remarked, “We thought, 'What the hell is going on here?' We were completely stumped.” Co-author Jane Edgeloe explained that the analysis of the DNA samples revealed the seagrass meadow's singular plant identity.

Remarkably, this plant is about three times the size of Manhattan, measuring at least 180 kilometers (112 miles) in length. Not only does it hold the title of the largest known plant, but it is also recognized as the largest clone in existence. The seagrass dwarfs the previously-held record of a 43-hectare colony of quaking Aspen trees in Utah, United States. It grows at a maximum rate of 35 centimeters per year, which helps researchers estimate its age accurately.

Dr. Elizabeth Sinclair, another co-author of the study, highlighted that the plant's ability to survive has been bolstered by retaining all chromosomes from both parent plants, resulting in genetic diversity—a rarity among asexually reproducing plants. While the plant does not reproduce sexually, small variations in its DNA could account for its longevity.

Associate Professor Kathryn McMahon from Edith Cowan University, who was not involved in the study but specializes in seagrass, shared that seagrass generally lives between 2,000 and 100,000 years. Thus, the estimated age of this plant at approximately 4,500 years aligns with typical seagrass lifespans. McMahon expressed confidence in the researchers' methods, finding it "amazing" that they confirmed it to be a single plant.

Despite its vast size, nearly 10% of the seagrass has been lost over the past decade due to cyclones and rising ocean temperatures, changes linked to climate change, as noted by NBC News. Additionally, the bay experiences relatively high salinity, with temperatures ranging from as cold as 10°C to as hot as 35°C.

title: Peltola defeats Palin, Begich in Alaska special election for US House of Representatives
content:
In a special election held on Wednesday, Democrat Mary Peltola secured Alaska's only seat in the United States House of Representatives, defeating Republican candidates Sarah Palin, the former governor of the state, and Nick Begich III, grandson of a former representative.

The election was necessitated by the passing of Representative Don Young, who had held the seat since 1973. 

Despite receiving only 40.20% of the votes in the initial round, Peltola benefited from Alaska's ranked-choice voting system, introduced in 2020. After Begich was eliminated as the candidate with the fewest votes, Peltola clinched the win with 51.47% of the final tally against Palin. She will now serve the remainder of Young's term until the upcoming election, which both Palin and Begich plan to contest.

Peltola's victory marks a significant milestone as she is the first Democrat to hold the seat since her predecessor Begich Sr. was presumed dead following a plane crash in 1972. CNN reporter Eric Bradner noted that Palin's defeat is likely to heighten concerns among Republicans about regaining control of the House. Political analyst Nathaniel Rakich characterized Palin as a "very flawed" and controversial candidate, suggesting that she was less likely than Begich to succeed in a direct contest against Peltola.

In response to her loss, Palin attributed the election results to the ranked-choice voting system, labeling it as "crazy, convoluted, and confusing." Begich, while congratulating Peltola, stated that "a vote for Sarah Palin is, in reality, a vote for Mary Peltola," arguing that Palin lacks sufficient support among Alaskans to win an election.

title: Pope Francis beatifies short-lived, 'smiling Pope' John Paul I
content:
Yesterday, in Vatican City, Pope Francis celebrated the beatification of his short-lived predecessor, Pope John Paul I, who led the Roman Catholic Church for just 33 days in 1978, in a ceremony attended by approximately 25,000 faithful.

Despite the rain, Pope Francis delivered a heartfelt homily, encouraging Catholics to pray for John Paul I, born Albino Luciani, to "obtain for us the smile of the soul." He remarked that "[with] a smile, Pope John Paul managed to communicate the goodness of the Lord" and praised him for "living without compromise, loving to the very end" as a "meek and humble pastor."

Albino Luciani, who was born into poverty in northern Italy in 1912, became a priest in 1935 and was elevated to cardinal in 1973. He was elected pope following the death of his predecessor on August 26, 1978, but tragically passed away just 33 days later on September 29, leading to the election of Pope John Paul II. In reflecting on John Paul I's legacy, Pope Francis stated: "How beautiful is a church with a happy, serene, and smiling face, that never closes doors, never hardens hearts, never complains or harbors resentment, does not grow angry or impatient, and does not look dour or suffer nostalgia for the past."

The beatification process for Pope John Paul I is the last step before sainthood and requires two verified miracles. Last year, Pope Francis attributed a miraculous recovery to him related to a critically ill Argentine girl, attributed to the prayers of her parents. A second miracle will need to be validated before he can be canonized.

Despite widespread skepticism, the circumstances surrounding John Paul I's unexpected death have fueled conspiracy theories, particularly following initial reports from the Vatican that mistakenly stated a priest discovered his body, later corrected to mention two nuns. The Vatican has declared that he died of a heart attack, but no autopsy was performed.

Stefania Falasca, the deputy supporting the push for John Paul I's sainthood and author of several books on him, denounced the conspiracy theories as "publicity-driven garbage." Cardinal and Vatican Secretary of State Pietro Parolin also addressed the rumors on Italian television, asserting: "It was a natural death. There is no mystery about it."

title: IAEA inspectors visit Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in Ukraine amid shelling, shutdown
content:
A team of 14 nuclear inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) arrived in southeast Ukraine yesterday, navigating ongoing shelling and an emergency shutdown of one of the reactors.

The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, the largest facility of its kind in Europe, has been under Russian control since March and remains an active combat zone. IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi acknowledged the "increased military activity in the area" but emphasized that the team would continue its mission without hesitation. Their arrival was reportedly delayed for several hours due to shelling in and around the nearby city of Enerhodar.

Ukraine's state nuclear power company, Energoatom, reported that shelling had caused the shutdown of the plant's fifth reactor, leaving only one operational. Both Ukraine and Russia have traded accusations of sabotage: Kyiv has alleged that Moscow shelled the route taken by IAEA inspectors.

In a related incident, Russia accused Ukraine of launching a failed amphibious assault to regain control of the facility early yesterday morning.

Grossi stated that the team’s immediate mission is to assess the security and safety situation at Zaporizhzhia, with the goal of establishing a permanent presence to stabilize the situation and provide regular, reliable updates. Russia's representative to the IAEA in Vienna expressed support for such a presence.

After assessing "key observations," some inspectors, including Grossi, have since departed, while five team members will remain until tomorrow, according to Energoatom. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy mentioned that journalists from Ukraine and abroad were not allowed to accompany the inspectors.

In other developments, Ukrainian forces are reportedly targeting supply lines around Russian-occupied cities in the southern part of the country.

title: Irish energy supplier Bord Gáis hikes rates for gas, electricity
content:
**Price Hikes for Residential Energy Customers in Ireland**

Ireland’s energy provider announced significant price increases yesterday, which will see residential customers facing an average additional charge of €48.25 for electricity and €43.80 for gas each month. This decision follows similar announcements from competitors including Electric Ireland and Prepay Power.

Effective October 2, electricity rates will rise by an average of 34%, while gas prices will increase by 39%. The supplier cited soaring wholesale energy costs as the driving factor behind this decision, stating, "these increases leave us with no choice." It's important to note that standing charges will remain unchanged. This translates to an annual increase of approximately €579 for electricity and €526 for gas, based on typical consumption figures of 4,200 kilowatt hours (kWh) for electricity and 11,000 kWh for gas.

On the same day, Russian energy giant Gazprom announced it would suspend natural gas supplies to Europe indefinitely via its pipeline due to a leak that requires repair.

Earlier this year, Bord Gáis raised costs for its 513,000 commercial and residential customers nationwide, implementing a 27% increase for electricity and a 39% hike for gas in March. In total, the company has raised electricity rates three times and gas rates twice over the past year. Daragh Cassidy of Bonkers.ie estimates that bills have increased by around €1,300 for electricity and €1,000 for gas since last year.

Cassidy noted, “The average gas and electricity bill now stands at about €4,000, nearing the UK price cap of £3,549," emphasizing that over 70% of Ireland's gas comes from the UK.

Bord Gáis Energy's managing director Dave Kirwan expressed regret over the need for these price hikes, citing the dramatic rise in wholesale energy costs and pledging to work towards minimizing the impact on customers. He announced that the company would allocate one-tenth of its operating profits to an energy support fund in collaboration with various organizations to assist those struggling to meet the increases.

A financial report from July 28 revealed that Bord Gáis' parent company based in the UK recorded a 74% rise in operating profits, reaching £33 million (€38 million) in the first half of 2022, partly due to a resurgence in activity.

The rising utility costs are intensifying pressure on the government, particularly in light of a €6.3 billion surplus observed in the eight months leading to August. Following Electric Ireland’s announcements of a 26.7% increase in residential electricity rates and a 37.5% increase in gas, Taoiseach Micheál Martin indicated that the European Commission would initiate emergency measures to address market challenges. He attributed the price hikes to a broader surge in energy costs and promised a strategy aimed at reducing overall energy consumption.

Addressing financial aid, Martin stated, "We will utilize the Budget along with a cost-of-living package to help alleviate pressures on households."

The significant surplus reported for the government was supported by unexpectedly high corporate tax revenues in August and robust gains in income tax collections. Finance Minister Paschal Donohoe emphasized the need to balance protection for vulnerable households and businesses amid the unprecedented energy price crisis while avoiding further inflationary pressures.

Opposition leader Mary Lou McDonald called for "an unprecedented, urgent and short-term response from the government," arguing that the current situation is unsustainable for individuals, families, and small businesses. She proposed measures such as a windfall tax on excess profits from energy companies, which the government is reportedly considering, as well as immediate price caps and broadened eligibility for fuel allowances.

European Union ministers are set to convene in Brussels next week to discuss immediate actions aimed at stabilizing gas prices and long-term market reforms over the coming year.

Additionally, the G7 countries, including EU members France, Germany, and Italy, agreed yesterday to implement a price ceiling on Russian oil, expected to take effect in December. The Russian government has reduced energy supplies to Europe since the invasion of Ukraine began, driving prices higher and risking blackouts across the continent. At the time of the Nord Stream 1 pipeline's operational suspension, it was supplying only a fifth of its daily capacity, according to energy consultancy firm Aurora's senior associate Jacob Mandel.

title: Proud Boys indicted for conspiracy over January 6 U.S. Capitol riots
content:
A Washington D.C. grand jury has indicted former Proud Boys chairman Enrique Tarrio and four other members of the far-right organization on charges related to the January 6 Capitol riot. This incident occurred when a large group of Donald Trump supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol to disrupt Congress's certification of the 2020 presidential election results. Prosecutors allege that the riot was premeditated rather than a spontaneous outburst.

Tarrio faces additional charges linked to the January 6 events; however, today's indictment marks a significant escalation. He, along with Proud Boys members Ethan Nordean, Joseph Biggs, Zachary Rehl, and Dominic Pezzola, is accused of conspiring to prevent then-President-elect Joe Biden from assuming office by organizing the riot. All five individuals have pleaded not guilty.

The indictment details how the accused allegedly met and strategized the assault on the Capitol, often using encrypted communications. Prosecutors claim they procured Baofeng radios to facilitate coordination among rioters without detection. On January 6, Proud Boys members purportedly breached metal barricades and led other rioters into the Capitol building. While Tarrio is accused of aiding in the planning, he did not enter the Capitol himself, having been arrested two days prior for vandalizing a Black Lives Matter banner, for which he served five months in prison.

The charge of "seditious conspiracy," which dates back to the Civil War era, could lead to a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison if the defendants are convicted.

Carmen Hernandez, attorney for Zachary Rehl, stated, "Seditious conspiracy requires the use of force, and [Rehl] never used any force nor thought about using any force."

Federal authorities have identified over three dozen Proud Boys members in leadership roles during the January 6 attack, with some having already pleaded guilty or agreed to cooperate with the prosecution.

The Proud Boys characterize themselves as "western chauvinists," and the Southern Poverty Law Center designates them as a hate group.
